{"uri": "2024-07-433037224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "08:59:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T08:59:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T08:45:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://aithority.com/machine-learning/apple-intelligence-the-latest-ai-privacy-challenge/", "title": "Apple Intelligence: the latest AI privacy challenge", "body": "At its Worldwide Developers Conference in June, Apple announced its long-anticipated move into AI, partnering with OpenAI to bring ChatGPT to iOS 18 which will start rolling out generally to users in September. Apple senior vice president of software engineering Craig Federighi calls its strategy \"a brand-new standard for privacy in AI\". Others however, including OpenAI founder Elon Musk were not so sure, threatening to ban the devices from his offices and branding it an 'unacceptable security violation'.\n\nMusk's outburst may be an overreaction, but it's symptomatic of some recent high-profile concerns around AI and data privacy and, in recent months, there's already been disquiet with data privacy issues surrounding Microsoft Recall, Slack, and Figma.\n\nHow will user data train OpenAI models? We don't know.\n\nApple has sought to reassure users that most of the new AI capabilities will run on device - and this would make business sense since the onus will be on users to upgrade to the latest models capable of running them. However, questions remain about other areas. For instance, Apple states that \"when requests are routed to Private Cloud Compute, data is not stored or made accessible to Apple, and is only used to fulfil the user's requests.\" Information on how user data is used to train OpenAI models is conspicuous in its absence. Furthermore, there may be different, competing data privacy preferences when users connect to their ChatGPT accounts. This should give individuals and corporations pause for thought - for now.\n\nAmbiguous AI privacy policies have become the norm\n\nSuch ambiguity is what we have come to expect from GenAI-enabled SaaS companies, and this is far from an isolated incident. In just the last few months, DocuSign updated its FAQ to state that \"if you have given contractual consent, we may use your data to train DocuSign's in-house, proprietary AI models\". Then, in May, a similar AI scare had Slack users up in arms with many criticizing vague data policies after it emerged that, by default, their data -- including messages, content, and files -- was being used to train Slack's global AI models. Reports remarked that 'it felt like there was no benefit to opting in for anyone but Slack.' After conducting our own research we found that such cases are just the tip of the iceberg and even the likes of LinkedIn, X, Pinterest, Grammarly, and Yelp have potentially risky content training declarations.\n\nPushing data boundaries\n\nAt the best of times, navigating data retention and content training declarations is hard work. More often, it's outright missing or heavily hidden, written in dense legal language, and subject to change over time. Vendors will continue pushing these boundaries as the global arms race to get ahead in AI accelerates. AI models need vast data sets to train them, and it means that vendors will be increasingly tempted to harvest as much data as they can and answer any questions later. This could be in the form of feature updates that, in effect, are a 'data grab' and deliver little value to the end user, or it could be in the form of vague policies deliberately designed to confuse which businesses unwittingly sign up to.\n\nPreviously it has been possible for organizations to turn off risky features until they have been properly understood, however we may be approaching a situation where these are so baked into the operating system that it becomes difficult to do. Can we (and should we) trust these companies to secure our data, or do we need to shift how we approach data protection?\n\nNavigating the minefield\n\nCurrently, organizations are in a tricky position - useful AI services, correctly implemented, can deliver huge productivity and innovation benefits. Simply blocking all is as risky as enabling all given firms can be left behind their peers. So what should firms do?\n\nFirstly, check the T&Cs - start with the most commonly used applications used in your organization but be aware that checking the text can be complicated as few services are forthcoming with exactly what types of data are used to train their models. The details are often buried and sometimes aren't referred to at all. Overarching privacy policies can often be the best place to guide decision-making but can change frequently so there is a need to review fairly regularly. Some of these do provide data training opt-outs, especially in the EU, which is another option for security teams.\n\nFocus on the apps you need - the challenge of understanding and tracking these T&Cs is exacerbated by the huge surge in Shadow AI. With such attention to detail required to oversee apps, it's helpful to have fewer apps to focus on. This means having honest conversations with employees to understand what services they are using and for what purpose to promote transparency and understanding of the risks posed by rogue AI adoption.\n\nIdentify Shadow AI - on the technical side, traditional cybersecurity tools like internet gateways and next-generation firewalls can also provide data to manually identify potential shadow AI instances. For companies using identity providers like Google, tracking \"Sign-in with Google\" activity can reveal unauthorized app usage. Specialized third-party solutions designed specifically to detect both shadow IT and shadow AI, can significantly improve an organization's ability to pinpoint and mitigate these technological threats.\n\nOne thing is for sure - AI only gets better the more data it has and organizations will need to carefully navigate the benefits and drawbacks of the services they use and the information shared with them.", "source": {"uri": "aithority.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AiThority"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, The task force aims to issue findings and reports and make policy recommendations to the Legislature regarding guidelines and potential legislation for AI systems.\n\nFriday's virtual meeting will include a public comment period for Washingtonians interested in participating. Speakers can sign up by emailing AI@atg.wa.gov at least 24 hours in advance, with remarks limited to two minutes. Written comments are accepted at any time. Details for joining the Zoom webinar are provided below.\n\nThose interested in watching the meeting live can stream it on the TVW website.\n\n\"Washington is already a technology leader in this country, and we must continue to lead on the safe and responsible use of AI,\" Ferguson said. \"The experts on our task force will be critical in helping shape policy that centers the people as we navigate one of the most important issues of our time.\"\n\nAI technology is rapidly developing, particularly generative AI -- which creates content such as text, images or audio -- has seen significant growth. Tools like ChatGPT have become some of the fastest-growing consumer internet applications ever.\n\nAccording to a recent survey, 79% of respondents in North America reported some exposure to generative AI. Forty-one percent report using it regularly, and 22% say they use it regularly at work. A study reported in Forbes found that half of Americans who interact with AI don't realize it.\n\nFerguson partnered with Sen. Joe Nguyen (D-White Center) to create the AI Task Force through Senate Bill 5838. Rep. Travis Couture (R-Allyn) sponsored the companion bill in the House. The bill passed with bipartisan support.\n\nIn June, Ferguson announced the experts who will serve on the task force as well as their scope of work.\n\nThe Attorney General's task force will consider {"uri": "8242781567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "09:48:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T09:48:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T09:47:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/dwp-embraces-generative-artificial-intelligence-after-controversy/180052/", "title": "DWP embraces generative artificial intelligence after controversy", "body": "Aiming to explore new opportunities and address challenges, the DWP's AI and Innovation Directorate is preparing to engage with suppliers to leverage generative AI across various domains.\n\nGenerative AI, renowned for its ability to create new content and solutions autonomously, has interested government bodies, including the DWP. Despite a recent ban on staff using ChatGPT, one of the leading AI tools, for official business, the department has conducted preliminary experiments to gauge its potential.\n\nThe initiative, outlined in newly published commercial documents, seeks proposals from suppliers capable of offering services in innovation, strategy development, scaling solutions, integration, and ongoing maintenance.\n\nThe DWP aims to capitalise on generative AI's capacity to revolutionise operations and unlock unforeseen opportunities.\n\nAcknowledging the transformative impact of artificial intelligence, the DWP highlighted its intention to navigate this technological frontier cautiously. A \"lighthouse program\" launched last year has provided a controlled environment to test generative AI tools, including an internal solution based on Microsoft's Copilot technology.\n\nEarlier uses of AI within the DWP have centred on enhancing operational efficiency, such as detecting fraud in Universal Credit claims. Despite criticism from civil society groups regarding transparency and potential biases in algorithmic decision-making, the department remains committed to expanding its AI capabilities.\n\nLooking ahead, the DWP plans to host an information session in August for suppliers listed on the Crown Commercial Service's AI DPS framework. This will be followed by an invitation for proposals from interested parties who complete a capability assessment.\n\nTo navigate the complexities and take opportunities presented by generative AI, the DWP emphasised the need for robust governance and ethical considerations. The department aims to strike a balance between innovation and accountability, ensuring that AI deployments serve the public interest effectively.\n\nWith a significant financial commitment earmarked for expanding AI applications in benefit management, the DWP's strategic embrace of generative AI underscores its determination to lead in adapting cutting-edge technologies to meet evolving societal {"uri": "8242854922", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:32:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:32:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:31:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/07/25/public-square/pr-newswire/dcgs-aipublishing-dazzle-at-the-34th-hktdc-hong-kong-book-fair/1959814", "title": "DCG's AI+Publishing Dazzle at the 34th HKTDC Hong Kong Book Fair", "body": "Bybit Web3 Livestream Explores Cultural Meme Coins and Other Trends\n\nHONG KONG, July 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- The 34th HKTDC Hong Kong Book Fair recently commenced at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center, where DCG, a pioneer in AI+Publishing, presented its impressive range of outcomes, drawing the attention of a large audience. During the exhibition, multiple Hong Kong publishers expressed their intent to engage in deep collaboration with DCG.\n\nDCG Booth at HKTDC Hong Kong Book Fair\n\nBOOKSGPT, crafted by DCG, is the large-scale AI model specifically tailored for the publishers. It offers comprehensive foundational technical support for critical aspects such as the publishing process, the construction of book knowledge bases, and services for reader interaction. To date, BOOKSGPT encompasses over 30 publishing scenarios and more than 20 book-related applications, successfully establishing a multi-modal dataset that spans the publishing industry. Through innovative training BOOKSGPT integrates multiple models, it has achieved precise data analysis of a full spectrum of books, real-time intelligent Q&A, and personalized resources recommendations, ushering in an era of AI transformation for the publishing industry.\n\nBuilding upon BOOKSGPT, DCG introduced the cutting-edge \"AI Editor Studio.\" The studio brings together 15 AI editors, including AI topic planning editors, AI authors, AI proofreading teams, and AI social media editors, each leveraging their expertise to collaborate across the entire publishing, printing, and distribution process. For instance, during the topic selection phase, AI topic planning editors can swiftly match similar author data, providing efficient advice for topic selection and even generating high-quality marketing analysis reports within three minutes. AI authors act as assistants to both authors and editors, adept at drafting outlines, generating content, preparing materials, and refining text. The AI proofreading team is capable of reviewing text, images, audio, and video content across multiple dimensions, ensuring robust support for every step of content review. As for distribution and marketing, AI social media editors can automatically generate social media copy-writing such as Facebook and Instagram posts, Tik-Tok live-stream scripts, Amazon reviews, or Quora answers, and quickly adapt to the rules of various social platforms, proposing precise strategic suggestions based on operational data.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nAt the venue, DCG also showcased \"Journey in Computer,\" a collaborative publication with Excellence Publication Company Limited, integrated with AI technology produced by DCG. These publications use QR codes as an entry point to match AI services with paper books, allowing readers to scan and access the AI services while reading. With the support of BOOKSGPT, each book is matched with an AI Assistant, which is able to provide real-time Q&As, engage, and analyze based on the content of the book, greatly enhancing the reading experience for each reader.\n\nDuring the fair, CEO Shi Qiming was invited to participate in the International Publishing Forum where he delivered a keynote speech titled \"Solution for Integrating AI and Publishing.\" He discussed the latest applications of AI in publishing and provided an in-depth analysis of how AI is bringing unprecedented opportunities and changes to this traditional industry. Shi Qiming believes that with the continuous penetration of AI technology and the increasing demands for reading experiences, the Hong Kong book market is poised for broader development prospects. At the fair, VP Michael Chen and the Global Business MD Larry Li held discussions with leaders of several Hong Kong publishers, reaching cooperation intentions and signing agreements, which laying a solid foundation for DCG's expansion into markets outside mainland China. Michael Chen stated that DCG's development in Hong Kong is a milestone of the company's going-out strategy, with a commitment to provide AI products and services for Hong Kong publishers and driving the Hong Kong publishing industry to a new era.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCONTACT: Jessica Chen, [email protected]\n\nAdvertisement", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8243164832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:47:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:47:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:46:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com/wall-street-ai-use-case-revenue-data-finance-2024-7", "title": "Wall Streeters sound off on their use of AI. But the real test will be if the tech can make their firms more money.", "body": "The question has dominated the business world for almost two years. Once ChatGPT graced us with its presence, everyone wanted to know how to leverage the tech to get ahead.\n\nWall Street, with its reams of data and need to analyze complex topics, has always been viewed as fertile ground for the AI revolution. So Business Insider's finance team spoke with almost three dozen finance workers across the industry about how they're using AI.\n\nFrom helping to identify startups to invest in to aggregating thousands of analyst notes to cutting down the time spent on busy work, AI use cases on the Street ran the gamut.\n\nOverall, generative AI typically helped finance professionals do their jobs faster, easier, or both.\n\nNot everyone is sold. Some don't see the \"breakthrough\" possibilities of the tech that so many have prophesied, finding it hard to see specific uses of AI in their own processes.\n\nAnd to be fair, they might not be wrong. As much as Wall Street likes to tout tech adoption, certain corners remain unchanged from decades ago, albeit with a few extra bells and whistles.\n\nNot unlike the workers it's looking to serve, gen AI's future on Wall Street will boil down to its ability to produce results.\n\nAI development doesn't come cheap. Whether you're starting from scratch or buying something off the shelf, there's plenty of costs to consider, from talent to hardware to retraining staff.\n\nBlackstone expects the US to spend roughly $1 trillion over the next five years building and facilitating new data centers that'll help power the gen AI wave.\n\nThat kind of cash means investors will want to see real changes in how things are done thanks to AI. It's a question Big Tech leaders are already fielding.\n\nOn Tuesday, Alphabet executives were pressed on whether Google's AI overview feature was generating more revenue for the firm, writes BI's Katherine Tangalakis-Lippert. And Nvidia has plans to show how its customers are making money using its AI chips when it reports earnings next month.\n\nThey won't be alone, as Goldman expects the market to keenly watch if AI spend can translate to revenue.\n\nAnd that's in tech where companies are supposed to take big swings on innovative projects! Now consider Wall Street, where ROI is built into the core of the industry.\n\nWill those firms continue pouring money into tech that can't improve their bottom line? In the end, finance workers' views on using generative AI, whatever they are, might not matter.\n\nThe Insider Today team: Dan DeFrancesco, deputy editor and anchor, in New York. Jordan Parker Erb, editor, in New York. Hallam Bullock, senior editor, in London. Annie Smith, associate producer, in London. Here's how AI is expected to influence key areas:\n\nAI's potential in healthcare is vast. From enhancing diagnostic accuracy to personalizing treatment plans, AI technologies are poised to revolutionize the sector. AI-powered tools can analyze medical images, predict disease outbreaks, and support telemedicine initiatives. These advancements promise to improve patient care and make healthcare services more accessible.\n\nAgriculture\n\nUsing artificial intelligence in the field of agriculture is essential for analyzing the land and deciding on water and pesticides amount, constant soil monitoring, and predicting climate change. The use of AI is providing farmers a tool that allows them to make better decisions regarding the farming process, increase yields and intelligently use resources. This innovation may solve the shortage of food and eventually nurture the planet by implementing agrarian systems that promote sustainability.\n\nEducation\n\nAI in education is a great way to provide students with individual learning experiences different from traditional ones. However, it offers a promise of automating administrative work as well as furnishing real-time feedback to students. Smart educational tools use AI and are able to adjust educational materials in such a way that each student can understand it in the best possible way, thus leading to an improvement in their learning outcomes and engagement with the learning process.\n\nTransportation\n\nAI is revolutionizing the transportation sector through inventions like self-driving cars, intelligent traffic management and predictive maintenance. Construction AI companies are at the forefront of this revolution, offering innovative solutions that enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and improve safety on job sites. As these technologies continue to evolve, they are poised to redefine how projects are planned, executed, and maintained.\n\nOne of the primary benefits of AI in construction is its ability to optimize project management. Construction AI companies provide tools that analyze vast amounts of data to predict project timelines, budget requirements, and resource allocation. This predictive capability allows project managers to make informed decisions, minimizing delays and cost overruns. For instance, AI algorithms can analyze historical data to forecast potential bottlenecks and suggest alternative strategies to keep projects on track.\n\nSafety is another critical area where construction AI companies are making a significant impact. AI-powered systems can monitor job sites in real-time, identifying potential hazards and ensuring compliance with safety regulations. For example, drones equipped with AI technology can perform site inspections, detecting risks such as structural weaknesses or unsafe working conditions. This proactive approach not only protects workers but also reduces the likelihood of costly accidents and legal issues.\n\nMoreover, AI is enhancing the design and planning phases of construction. Advanced software developed by construction AI companies can generate detailed 3D models and simulations, allowing architects and engineers to visualize projects before they break ground. These models can be used to identify design flaws, optimize material usage, and streamline construction processes. By integrating AI into the design phase, companies can achieve higher precision and efficiency, resulting in better-quality structures and reduced waste.\n\nIn conclusion, the integration of AI in the construction industry is transforming traditional practices and setting new standards for efficiency, safety, and quality. Construction AI companies are leading this charge, providing cutting-edge tools and technologies that are revolutionizing how we build. As AI continues to advance, its impact on the construction sector will only grow, driving innovation and excellence in an industry that is crucial to our modern world, highlighted in Global Construction AI Companies Market report. In construction, IBM's AI-driven Watson platform provides advanced analytics, predictive maintenance, and project management solutions. These capabilities help construction companies optimize operations, reduce downtime, and enhance decision-making processes.\n\nMicrosoft, founded in 1975 and headquartered in Redmond, Washington, offers AI and cloud solutions through its Azure platform. Solutions like Dynamics 365 and HoloLens enhance project visualization, resource planning, and on-site safety, driving efficiency and innovation in construction workflows.\n\nOracle, established in 1977 and headquartered in Austin, Texas, delivers comprehensive cloud and AI solutions for the construction sector. Oracle's Construction and Engineering Cloud offers project management, scheduling, and risk management tools. Their AI-driven analytics enable construction firms to optimize project execution, enhance productivity, and mitigate risks, ensuring successful project delivery.\n\nSAP, founded in 1972 and headquartered in Walldorf, Germany, provides enterprise software solutions that integrate AI and machine learning. For the construction industry, SAP's solutions like SAP S/4HANA offer real-time data analytics, resource management, and predictive maintenance. These tools help construction companies streamline operations, improve decision-making, and enhance overall project performance.\n\nBuilt Robotics, founded in 2016 and based in San Francisco, California, specializes in autonomous construction equipment. Their technology transforms traditional heavy machinery, such as excavators and bulldozers, into fully autonomous robots using AI and advanced sensors. {"uri": "2024-07-433490795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:36:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:36:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:29:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2803297/", "title": "As K-pop groups experiment with AI, its future in music is uncertain", "body": "One of music's biggest genres is experimenting with the power of artificial intelligence after K-pop group Seventeen used AI to help promote their single's music videoMaestro.\n\nThe song is a hit, but the use of AI in this multi-billion dollar industry has received mixed reviews.\n\n\"Some people are really for it, some are really against it. But I think the use of generative AI is here to stay,\" said Michelle Cho, an assistant professor of Korean studies at the University of Toronto. The flow guest host Rebecca Zandbergen.\n\nThe clip of Maestro features the 13 members of the band performing while surrounded by robots and other pieces of technology.\n\nThe teaser trailer, released in April,features segments created by generative AIand shows people playing classical music with robots in the background, and robots playing on what looks like some kind of high-tech keyboard.\n\n\"The whole theme of Maestro is a kind of commentary on how humans and their creative energy [are] \"We are threatened by media technologies,\" Cho said.\n\nK-pop is a multi-billion dollar industry, with South Korea to become world's seventh largest music market by 2023according to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry. With so much money to be made, artists and agencies are looking for ways to use AI in innovative ways.\n\nCho says the members of Seventeen are known in the K-pop community for being involved in writing their music and choreographing their performances.\n\nAnd with popular boy band BTS on hiatus during their mandatory military service in South Korea, Seventeen has benefited from the opening. The group sold 16 million albums last year.\n\nBut the group sparked controversy in April when comments made by one of the group members, Woozihas led people to wonder if the band used generative AI to write the songs for their latest album. He has since denied the allegations.claiming that the band's music is \"written and composed by human creators.\"\n\n\"A lot of fans have taken to social media platforms to express their anger at how the band has been misrepresented, because fans, I think, don't necessarily support the use of AI or the idea that artists' creativity should be overshadowed by AI,\" Michelle said.\n\nBut it's clear that K-pop groups are finding ways to use generative AI. Bernie Cho, president of creative agency DFSB Kollective, says the technology has become ubiquitous in the K-pop industry.\n\nHe says some artists are using AI to translate their lyrics, helping artists create songs in languages they wouldn't otherwise be able to sing in.\n\n\"I work with independent artists who really want to become more global, faster, bigger, better, and they use AI to quickly translate their Korean lyrics into multiple languages,\" Bernie Cho said.\n\nBands are also using AI to create art, he says, not just for albums but for every single they release, giving each song a unique feel.\n\nThere are even artists using AI to create artificially generated performers who sing and dance, all with a real person behind the wheel fine-tuning the project.\n\n\"We're starting to see AI groups battling for rankings with real groups,\" Bernie Cho said.\n\nAnd since the job still requires someone pulling the strings, he says he's not worried about AI taking over the industry.\n\n\"I don't think it's going to put me out of work. On the contrary, it's going to allow me to do more work, faster, better, bigger, easier. And so, if I can afford anything, I'm very grateful for the advent of AI.\"\n\nLegal Issues Related to Generative AI\n\nAI faces a handful of challenges, both in K-pop and other genres.\n\nFans haven't yet fully embraced the idea of an all-AI act, partly because there are a lot of things an AI can't do, like sign autographs or meet fans in person.\n\n\"Even though it looks cool from a distance, what we hear from fans is that it's not that cool. It's actually a little bit cold,\" Bernie Cho said.\n\nCharlie Harding, music journalist and host of the show Pop lit podcast, says there is also quality to consider.\n\n\"We generally like to hear songs that we think are made by an artist, that speak to an inner truth,\" he said.\n\nThen there are the legal disputes. Artists are looking formore protection against AI scanning their work to create its own.\n\nMajor music groups such as Universal Music Group, Warner Music Group and Sony Music Group have all filed lawsuits against AI music generators Suno and Udio.\n\nIn May, the The South Korean government has announced plans to revise copyright laws regarding AIto \"support the development of the AI-based creative industry.\"\n\nEfforts like these could change the way the industry uses AI, Harding says.\n\n\"If we start to see precedents emerging in court cases that say, 'No, you can't do that,' those cases could really determine the future of how we use these big language models,\" he said.\n\n\"I think artificial intelligence, in one form or another, is here to stay. As it stands, its use is yet to be determined.\"", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242698642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "08:56:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T08:56:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T08:56:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.techerati.com/news-hub/quantum-ai-framework-developed-to-cut-data-centre-energy-consumption-by-12-5/", "title": "Quantum AI framework developed to cut data centre energy consumption by 12.5% - Techerati", "body": "Researchers at Cornell University have developed a quantum computing framework that could reduce energy use in artificial intelligence (AI) data centres by 12.5% and cut carbon emissions by 10%.\n\nThis intersection of quantum computing and AI technology known as Quantum AI represents a promising field with enormous potential. Quantum AI leverages principles from quantum mechanics to improve AI algorithms, potentially surpassing the capabilities of classic computing AI models.\n\nThe framework, created by Professor Fengqi You and Akshay Ajagekar, a graduate student, focuses on utilising hybrid quantum-classical methods to improve the efficiency of energy management in AI data centres. They approximated variational quantum circuit net load demand in a simulated digital twin, managing controls with an uncertainty-aware formulation.\n\nThe model demonstrated positive results in both energy efficiency and decarbonisation.\n\n\"By developing quantum computing-based AI methods, we are tackling the pressing energy and climate challenges faced by AI data centres, significantly enhancing their sustainability and efficiency,\" You said.\n\nThe energy consumption of regular data centres is of concern to a variety of different stakeholders. Energy represents a large portion of operating costs for data centre owner/operators, so reducing consumption can have a positive impact on the bottom line.\n\nEnvironmental agencies and activists are concerned with the impact of high levels of energy consumption on green data centre initiatives; while residents that live near data centres are increasingly concerned with the strain these facilities put on the electrical grid.\n\nAll of these concerns are growing more intense with the advent of the AI data centre, which is expected to require far more energy to operate than a classic data centre. In fact, Goldman Sachs predicted AI will increase data centre energy demands by 160% by 2030.\n\nWith these predictions in mind, finding new ways to reduce data centre energy consumption is critical. If it proves effective in a live data centre, a Quantum AI solution elegantly applies the source of the issue, increased use of AI, to find a solution to the problem of increased energy requirements.\n\nIn April, a recent report from the International Energy Agency (IEA) found data centre energy consumption could double by 2026, attributed to the increase in the adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) and cryptocurrency.", "source": {"uri": "techerati.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Techerati"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nicole_cappella@techerati.com", "name": "Nicole {"uri": "8242823956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:12:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:12:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:12:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://advocacy.consumerreports.org/press_release/consumer-reports-survey-many-americans-concerned-about-ai-algorithms", "title": "Consumer Reports survey: Many Americans concerned about AI, algorithms", "body": "Nationally representative survey looks at consumer attitudes toward artificial intelligence and algorithmic decision-making on matters related to shopping, housing, employment, and healthcare\n\nWashington, DC - A new nationally representative Consumer Reports survey explores Americans' attitudes toward artificial intelligence (AI) and algorithmic decision-making. The survey found that a majority of Americans are uncomfortable about the use of AI and algorithmic decision-making technology around major life moments as it relates to housing, employment, and healthcare. CR conducted this multi-mode survey of 2,022 US adults in May 2024. The full report also includes demographic insights.\n\nGrace Gedye, policy analyst at CR, said, \"Companies are using AI and algorithms behind the scenes to help determine everything from decisions about your health insurance coverage, to your prospects of landing your dream job, to who is going to get that perfect apartment you found on Zillow. We conducted this survey to get a better understanding of how consumers feel about the role AI and algorithms play in these high stakes decisions.\"\n\n\"The survey shows that a majority of Americans are uncomfortable with the use of AI in high-stakes decisions about their lives. We also found that in certain circumstances, Americans really want to understand what information an AI system is using to assess them, and want the chance to correct any incorrect information. Consumer Reports advocates for regulations that require AI systems to be more transparent, and that give consumers agency.\"\n\nKey findings of the survey includes:\n\nAttitudes toward AI/algorithms making marketing decisions\n\nPersonalized pricing\n\nDiscomfort with AI programs making decisions that affect people's lives\n\nTransparency and recourse\n\nConsumer Reports advocates for legislation at the state and federal level to protect consumers from algorithmic discrimination and other AI-related harms. Clear standards are needed regarding the responsible use of AI across multiple industries so that companies are accountable for ensuring their products are safe, effective, and do not manipulate, deceive or discriminate. Consumers should be informed when AI tools make high-stakes decisions about them, and should have agency, such as the opportunity to correct any incorrect information and the opportunity to appeal a decision.\n\nConsumer Reports has been pushing for state legislation that would require companies to disclose more information about how AI tools they use in consequential decisions assess consumers. Colorado's new law, which goes into effect in 2026, will require companies to provide consumers and workers with an explanation after a company uses AI to make an adverse, high-stakes decision about him or her. California lawmakers are considering a similar bill, currently backed by CR, that would provide consumers with even more detailed information about how a consumer or worker will be assessed by an AI tool, as well as actionable post-decision explanations.\n\nCR published an AI policy guide in March that outlines our key positions and recommendations for policymakers.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8242962459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:36:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:36:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:36:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://capx.co/bad-rules-are-jeopardising-britains-ai-revolution/", "title": "Bad rules are jeopardising Britain's AI revolution", "body": "Unlocking investment and driving economic growth are two of the key missions of Keir Starmer's new government. Yet for artificial intelligence - one of the UK's highest growth industries - investments risk being held back by a lack of alignment between the Government and the competition regulator.\n\nWhile the UK has sought to position itself as the leading AI hub in Europe, the Competition and Markets Authority has decided to focus on risks rather than the opportunities of AI. Until this disconnect is addressed, the UK risks losing its edge in the field.\n\nAt present, the UK is home to the most AI firms in Europe, totalling over 1,680, according to the Global AI Ecosystem database, with the total value of the sector expected to reach $1 trillion globally by 2035. These companies are already making important advancements, notably in healthcare, where AI is streamlining complex ultrasound measurements to diagnose heart conditions and enabling earlier detection of cancer. As a result, the UK is well positioned to be the European leader in a sector which is projected to reach $1 trillion in value by 2035.\n\nHowever, the small businesses that are championing AI innovation face major barriers to success. Crucially, they need vast amounts of investment to pay in-demand talent and buy vast amounts of 'compute capacity': thousands of servers with specialised chips that execute trillions of operations to power large language models. Therefore, AI firms are under immense pressure to scale and deploy their products at pace. Each company is, in essence, racing to deploy a commercially viable product before their funding runs out.\n\nAs a consequence, small AI businesses are almost entirely dependent on capital injections to manage both astronomical costs and major business challenges. And, so far, it has been the established tech companies that have stepped up, entering into partnerships with AI startups, to provide the backing that these innovators need.\n\nHowever, the CMA considers this support an area of 'increasing concern' due to supposed market concentration risks and is even going as far as to investigate whether non-controlling investments between separate non-British companies should be subject to scrutiny under the Enterprise Act.\n\nThis is alarming not only for investors in these smaller AI companies, but also for the innovators themselves. When a regulator steps in and challenges an investment, it does not just put one partnership at risk; it deters others. This begs the question as to whether the CMA is actually supporting AI innovation as it says it does.\n\nInvestors fundamentally look for markets where government and regulators are working toward a shared vision for the economy, without this they will rightly look elsewhere. The new government must now decide if they want the UK to lead the way in AI innovation, with all the economic growth and high-skilled jobs this involves. If so, they must work with the CMA to present a shared vision for a British AI economy. Without this, investment will remain out of reach and growth opportunities will remain untapped.\n\nClick here to subscribe to our daily briefing - the best pieces from CapX and across the web.\n\nCapX depends on the generosity of its readers. If you value what we do, please consider making a donation.\n\nDr Liza Lovdahl Gormsen is Senior Research Fellow in Competition Law and Director at the Competition Law Forum.\n\nColumns are the {"uri": "8243583985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:13:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:13:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:13:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://njbiz.com/up-to-500m-in-ai-tax-credits-available-via-next-nj-program/", "title": "Up to $500M in AI tax credits available via Next NJ Program", "body": "The Garden State took its latest step in establishing itself as a leader in the artificial intelligence space, as Gov. Phil Murphy signed legislation into law July 25 establishing the Next New Jersey Program.\n\nThe initiative aims to attract new investment into the state's AI industry, providing up to $500 million in tax credits for AI businesses. The incentives were originally allocated for the Aspire and Emerge programs. Assembly Bill 4558/Senate Bill 3432 was passed alongside the Fiscal Year 2025 state budget as that process came down the home stretch.\n\nThe Thursday signing ceremony took place at the Roseland headquarters of CoreWeave. Founded in a New Jersey suburban garage, the AI cloud infrastructure company has grown into a global company and leader in this space.\n\n\"We're here today to sign a piece of legislation that will empower our state's top minds to shape the future of generative artificial intelligence - both ambitiously and responsibly,\" said Murphy. \"Because in a moment when the future of this realm has yet to be written, we here in New Jersey can be one of its prime authors. And together, in partnership with our state's innovators, researchers and industry leaders like CoreWeave - we can unleash a new generation of possibilities that will transform our world for the better.\"\n\nCoreWeave co-founder and Chief Strategy Officer Brian Venturo thanked Murphy and his administration for their leadership and investment in the AI space. He stressed this legislation will position New Jersey as a premiere hub for AI innovation.\n\n\"Governor, your presence here today is not only a testament to your commitment to the advancement of technology, but also your unwavering support for the AI business community in our state,\" said Venturo. \"Your dedication to fostering an environment where companies like ours can thrive has not gone unnoticed. We are grateful for your leadership and vision.\"\n\nVenturo said the bill signing is definitive proof that New Jersey is open for AI business.\n\n\"This not only reinforces New Jersey's heritage as a state of innovators but also paves the way for significant advancements and opportunities for AI development,\" said Venturo. \"As the AI Hyperscaler, CoreWeave is proud to be headquartered here and excited to continue driving this industry forward.\"\n\nPrimary sponsors of the legislation Sen. Raj Mukherji, D-32nd District, and Assemblyman Chris Tully, D-38th District, were on hand for the event.\n\n\"From life-saving health care breakthroughs to traffic jams, artificial intelligence will touch every aspect of our daily lives,\" said Mukherji, a former information technology CEO. \"Through the responsible incentives in the Next New Jersey legislation, we are cementing New Jersey's place at the forefront of technological advancement and economic competitiveness as we tap into the transformative potential of AI.\"\n\n\"The Next New Jersey Program is a bold step forward in making our state a leading hub for the rapidly evolving AI industry and ensure we continue building a prosperous and innovative future all of New Jersey,\" said Tully. \"New Jersey's investment lets industry know our state is a competitive and committed leader in AI.\"\n\n\"The bill I'm signing today - and again I want to thank Raj and Chris and their colleagues - will invest up to $500 million into building out New Jersey's AI infrastructure. $500 million,\" said Murphy, who also credited the New Jersey Economic Development Authority and its leadership for their efforts in shaping the legislation.\n\n\"And with this investment, we're going to make it far easier for our state's students, researchers, entrepreneurs - you name it, who share our commitment to innovating responsibly to explore the potential of their AI-powered innovations,\" Murphy said. \"We want our state government to be a catalyst for pairing together established players in the world of AI like CoreWeave, with young innovators who are just getting their start.\"\n\nMurphy said the legislation reflects the state's continued efforts and big bets into AI and innovation. He pointed to the establishment of the AI Task Force and the AI Hub at Princeton, as well as innovation hubs such as HAX, SciTech Scity and more.\n\n\"Let me be clear, CoreWeave is one of the hottest companies on the planet. Their reach is hyperglobal,\" said Murphy. \"They could have planted their headquarters flag anywhere, literally - and they chose the great State of New Jersey.\"\n\n\"What a momentous day,\" said NJEDA Chief Executive Officer Tim Sullivan. \"This is a continuation of our journey to making New Jersey the most diverse and inclusive innovation ecosystem America - and recapturing our leadership position in innovation and entrepreneurship.\"\n\nSullivan spoke about the potential scale of AI. He analogized it to the early internet, referencing recent comments from Microsoft's Brad Smith at the AI Summit comparing the technology to the printing press.\n\n\"I am big with these metaphors. I think you can't miss for what generative AI represents for the future our society; of our economy; of our state; and of our country and our world,\" said Sullivan. \"And so, this bill that the governor is going to sign, I think, really positions New Jersey to make smart and targeted investment to support not just the AI industry - but all of New Jersey's economic competitiveness. Because being on our front foot with regard to generative AI is going to be like 20-25 years ago thinking - we should probably have a good internet infrastructure; and companies should have websites - those kinds of innovative ideas.\"\n\nMurphy closed his comments by saying it is important to look in the mirror and ask: who are you, who are you not, and what can you be and what can you not be?\n\n\"I've said this many times - I'm going to die, probably, trying to make cars and trucks again in New Jersey. But when I look in the mirror, I don't see that,\" said Murphy. \"What I do see is an innovation economy. I see with proof points up and down our state - biopharma, life sciences, tech, telecom, film/television, digital, the green economy, offshore wind, fintech, the guts of the sports betting business. That's who we are. We lead with talent; we lead with innovation; we lead with our location.\"\n\nHe said that his administration decided early, collectively and affirmatively to make an all-in bet on generative AI.\n\n\"The creation of this program will support the growth of AI-related businesses, which could lead to scientific breakthroughs and lifesaving discoveries right in our backyard,\" said Murphy. \"AI will be a transformative industry that will change lives and grow our economy - and New Jersey is ready to take the lead.\"", "source": {"uri": "njbiz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NJBIZ"}, "dmoz/Society/Activism/In_Daily_Life", "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism/In Daily Life", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 86}], "image": "https://njbiz.com/files/2024/07/Murphy_CoreWeave-AI.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761468", "eventUri": "eng-9761468", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-25", "textStart": 159, "textEnd": 166}], "sentiment": 0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 127, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243391805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:26:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:26:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:25:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://fortune.com/2024/07/25/ai-olympics-paris-2024-says-a-lot-about-ai-promise-and-perils/", "title": "AI goes to the Olympics", "body": "The 2024 Olympic Games kick off tomorrow in Paris, where over 10,000 athletes will compete in 329 events. Also in attendance: a whole lot of AI.\n\nFrom the broadcasts to security, AI is being infused heavily throughout the Paris games. It's not exactly surprising in this moment when AI is dominating, but what is interesting is the extent to which AI's presence at the Olympics provides a snapshot of how broadly AI is quickly being implemented in so many different areas from live events to broadcast, advertising, athlete performance, law enforcement, and state surveillance.\n\nOverall the International Olympic Committee (IOC) said it's determined over 180 potential use cases for AI in the Olympics, some of which will be on display this summer. AI tools will also assist athletes with analyzing sporting performance and will additionally be deployed to \"enhance the fairness and accuracy of judging and refereeing through the provision of precise metrics,\" according to IOC. Beyond the competitions themselves, some of the ways AI is being used at the Olympics seem like nothing more than marketing gimmicks, while others show how the technology could change how we interact with events and content. Then there's the more controversial use case of surveillance that has privacy and civil liberty advocates sounding the alarm.\n\nLast week, it was announced that Google has been named \"the official search AI partner of Team USA,\" marking the first time the sports organization has partnered with a tech company. Commentators with NBCUniversal -- which continues to hold exclusive American media rights to the games -- will use Google's new AI search overviews to answer questions about the sports on-air. NBC has also recruited Comedian Leslie Jones to serve as \"Chief Superfan Commentator,\" a role that seemingly mixes entertaining fans with showing off how Google's Gemini assistant works.\n\nThe U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee put out a statement hyping up the Google collaboration as a \"powerful alliance that brings together the best of technology and sports\" that will \"inspire millions.\" Even without the grandiose language, it seems like a huge stretch. Does anyone really want to watch sports commentators Google live on the air? I would bet no, but clearly, this is serving more as an ad for Google's AI than a good use of the technology. There's a reason Google struck this first-of-its-kind deal, likely paying a pretty penny. (Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.)\n\nAs we know, these models are still prone to making up and delivering false information. There's a high chance the answers Gemini delivers will be less accurate than if the broadcast team researched the questions themselves. The same goes for the chatbot, powered by Intel, the IOC is rolling out for participating athletes to ask frequently asked questions regarding guidelines and procedures.\n\nPrior to this Google deal, however, NBCUniversal announced a brand new way for fans to watch Olympic content that could actually enhance the experience and simply wouldn't be possible without generative AI. The new feature, called Your Daily Olympic Recap, will provide users with personalized recaps of their favorite events complete with commentary provided by an AI version of legendary sportscaster Al Michaels's voice. Users can set up their preferences and then receive a personalized recap every day of the Olympics through the Peacock app, NBC's streaming platform that will also be airing the games.\n\nTo create the recaps, the language model behind the feature will analyze subtitles and metadata from NBC's Olympic coverage to create summaries of the events. It will then rewrite those summaries in Michaels's style before feeding them into a text-to-voice model. With so many different events happening simultaneously, the Olympics is not exactly easy to keep up with. Your Daily Olympic Recap actually solves a problem by compiling the parts you're most interested in and wrapping them up in a neat package. Using Michael's voice is the perfect bow on top, providing that legendary commentary sports fans have grown to love and expect. Time will tell if this feature works as planned, but NBC gets credit for using AI in an interesting way that actually solves a problem, rather than AI for AI's sake.\n\nEvent organizers and the French government are also leaning on AI to monitor potential threats. Specifically, AI-powered cameras will be used to track crowd movement and detect any activity considered unusual, from suspicious luggage to traffic violations. They'll also be collecting geolocation data and deploying camera-equipped drones. Earlier this year, the French government actually changed its laws in order to allow this use of the technology for the Olympics, passing Article 7 (a controversial provision that legalized AI-powered video surveillance before, during, and after the games) and Article 10 (which specifically permits the use of AI software to review video and camera feeds). While the technology technically isn't based on facial recognition, many have argued that Article 7 in particular violates GDPR, the EU's data privacy law which prohibits the processing of biometric data and gives citizens the right to have their personal data erased. It's also a tight line to walk in light of the newly enacted EU AI Act, which explicitly bans the use of live facial recognition systems by law enforcement.\n\nWhile acknowledging that such a large-scale event requires increased security, data privacy researchers and civil liberty advocates have raised concerns about giving the private technology companies involved access to thousands of cameras around France. The vague nature of how exactly the technology will be used also raises questions about what activity counts as unusual or suspicious and thus is subjected to increased surveillance, as well as how the data will be stored -- and potentially used in the future. While the French Government changed the law specifically for the Olympics, the provision allows for usage of the technology far beyond the end of the games.\n\nAnne Toomey McKenna, a law professor and attorney focused on the intersection of privacy, AI, and surveillance, argued in The Conversation that the French government and private tech sector are harnessing the legitimate need for increased security as grounds to deploy advanced surveillance and data gathering tools.\n\n\"Flagging these events seems like a logical and sensible use of technology. But the real privacy and legal questions flow from how these systems function and are being used,\" she wrote. \"How much and what types of data have to be collected and analyzed to flag these events? What are the systems' training data, error rates and evidence of bias or inaccuracy? What is done with the data after it is collected, and who has access to it? There's little in the way of transparency to answer these questions.\"\n\nMistral unveils its next-generation flagship model. That's according to VentureBeat. The day after Meta announced Llama 3.1 to challenge the closed frontier models from companies like OpenAI and Google, French AI startup Mistral followed suit with its own partially open new release. Called Mistral Large 2, the company says it's significantly more capable in code generation, mathematics, and reasoning than its predecessor and also offers much stronger multilingual support. The model contains 123 billion parameters, and while that's much fewer than Llama 3.1's 405 billion, Mistral says the model can run on a single H100 node. As my Eye on AI coauthor Jersey Kahn wrote on Tuesday, Llama 3.1's gargantuan size comes with some hefty challenges around the number of GPUs required to run the model and the expertise needed to manage such a distributed workload. When it comes to the Mistral Large 2's openness, however, it only stretches as far as noncommercial uses. For commercial applications, companies must obtain a separate license and usage agreement from Mistral.\n\nMicrosoft launches generative AI search results for Bing. That's according to TechCrunch. Much like Google's generative AI-powered search, Bing will now share summaries in response to users' search inquiries, created by AI from sources across the web. Bing says it will cite and link to the pages where the information stems from. The new search experience is currently only available to a small percentage of users. In its initial days, Google's generative AI search infamously suggested to users that they eat rocks and put glue on pizza, so we'll see how this goes.\n\nDeepfakes of Kamala Harris are going viral. Media Matters said fake audio of Harris started spreading like wildfire following President Joe Biden's announcement that he won't seek reelection and the subsequent wave of support for Harris as the Democratic nominee. The audio falsely depicts Harris sounding incoherent and slurring and was manipulated from a speech she gave at Howard University last year. Media Matters found that right-wing accounts are pushing the audio and that users have wrongly attributed it to Harris in order to attack her. TikTok has since removed the audio, but Mashable reports it's spread on Elon Musk's X as well. While the audio appears to be manipulated rather than generated by AI, the rise of widely available AI tools has made false depictions of political figures a top-of-mind issue. In May, a Senate committee passed three bills aimed at protecting elections from AI-generated deepfakes, but they have not advanced to become law.\n\nOpenAI may be on track to lose $5 billion this year and may need additional funding within 12 months. That's according to an analysis performed by The Information based on OpenAI financial figures it said it obtained and unnamed sources it said were familiar with the company's finances and spending. This would be a burn rate so high that the company, which received a $10 billion cash injection from Microsoft in 2023, would have to seek additional funding soon -- probably within the next year -- despite reportedly also being on course to make more than $2 billion in revenue this year. The publication's analysis, however, is based on a number of extrapolations, estimates, and assumptions about how much OpenAI is spending to rent data center capacity from Microsoft Azure, as well as how quickly the cost of training OpenAI's latest frontier models is ramping up. Those assumptions might not be correct. But if they are even in the ballpark, they point to a business that is nowhere close to becoming profitable. The publication pointed out that OpenAI may be in better shape than its rival Anthropic, which may be losing about half as much money but on a much lower revenue base.\n\nA day after raising $500 million, AI startup Cohere told staff it was laying off about 20 employees -- by Sharon Goldman\n\nGM-owned Cruise has lost interest in cars without steering wheels. Its competitors haven't -- by Jessica Mathews\n\nExclusive: Lakera snags $20 million to prevent business Gen AI apps from going haywire and revealing sensitive data -- by Sharon Goldman\n\nTesla shares plunged on weak earnings. But a top analyst says AI investments will lead to a $1 trillion-plus valuation -- by Sheryl Estrada\n\nAI could become the 'new steel' as overcapacity risk goes unnoticed -- by Susan Ariel Aaronson (Commentary)\n\nJuly 21-27: International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), Vienna, Austria\n\nDec. 8-12: Neural Information Processing Systems (Neurips) 2024 in Vancouver, British Columbia.\n\nDec. 9-10: Fortune Brainstorm AI San Francisco (register here)\n\nThat's how much faster Smoothie King's chief legal officer has been able to review contracts using AI, Ironclad told Eye on AI. Using IronClad's software, the company has tagged and indexed over 4,000 contracts, generated net-new contract language, and was able to more easily cover for a colleague out on parental leave. Overall, Ironclad said 75% of its customers are now using its AI features to negotiate contracts, tag and index contracts, and surface insights.\n\nThe legal industry has been quick to pursue ways to benefit from new generative AI technologies, and tackling the tedious and repetitive nature of contracts has been of particular interest. IronClad is just one of dozens of companies offering legal copilots to automate contracts and legal work for both law firms and corporate legal companies. Earlier this week, OpenAI-backed legal startup Harvey raised an additional $100 million at a $1.5 billion valuation.", "source": {"uri": "fortune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fortune"}, {"uri": "8243123550", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:18:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/granica-delivers-ai-safe-room-solution-granica-screen-through-google-cloud-marketplace/article_a866e82c-ef82-5286-8145-4fa35da45a2e.html", "title": "Granica Delivers AI Safe Room Solution Granica Screen Through Google Cloud Marketplace", "body": "MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Jul 25, 2024--\n\nGranica, a leader in data management for AI, today announced the availability of Granica Screen on Google Cloud Marketplace, providing customers with advanced tools for the safe, ethical, and responsible development and deployment of AI. This marks a significant milestone for Granica, as it continues to expand its reach and offer cutting-edge technologies that address critical challenges at the intersection of data privacy and AI development.\n\nGoogle Cloud Marketplace is designed for Google Cloud partners to offer software solutions that operate on or integrate with Google Cloud like Compute Engine or Cloud Storage, with no manual configuration required. By listing Granica Screen on Google Cloud Marketplace, Granica ensures that enterprises can quickly and seamlessly integrate this powerful solution into their existing workflows, accelerating time to value and reducing operational complexity.\n\nGranica Screen enables enterprises to navigate key challenges involved with using, building, and scaling generative AI, including maximizing data utility, controlling runtime leaks and exposures, and mitigating compliance risks. It does this by delivering a \"Safe Room for AI\", a specialized data processing environment for tabular and natural language processing (NLP) datasets, via a powerful combination of AI privacy and safety capabilities for use across model pre-training, fine-tuning, inference and RAG.\n\nKey benefits for customers:\n\nLLM Runtime Protection: Dynamically discover, mask and de-mask sensitive information discovered in LLM prompts and RAG to safeguard model inputs and outputs and prevent leakage by models.Anonymizing Training Data: Discover, mask and anonymize sensitive information discovered in source training data sets to enable safe use in model pre-training and fine-tuning.Ethical AI Development: Evaluate source training data sets for toxicity and bias to help ensure AI models perform ethically and fairly. Available via early access program for select customers.Streamlining Compliance: Discover sensitive information in cloud data lake files and proactively remediate identified data vulnerabilities to adhere to GDPR, CCPA, PCI DSS, HIPAA, and more.\n\n\"We are thrilled to join Google Cloud Marketplace and make our Safe Room for AI more accessible to enterprises looking to safely and efficiently build and use AI,\" said Rahul Ponnala, CEO and co-founder of Granica. \"Our partnership with Google Cloud will enable us to deliver even greater value to our customers, helping them unlock the full potential of their data to drive greater AI outcomes.\"\n\n\"Bringing Granica to Google Cloud Marketplace will help customers quickly deploy, manage, and grow the Granica Screen on Google Cloud's trusted, global infrastructure,\" said Dai Vu, Managing Director, Marketplace & ISV GTM Programs at Google Cloud. \"Granica can now securely scale and support customers on their digital transformation journeys.\"\n\nGranica Screen is purpose-built for AI at scale. It offers superior discovery accuracy, outperforming low-fidelity ML and regex-based solutions in precision and recall, with support for over 100 languages and over 100 named-entities across diverse data modalities. Screen is cost-effective for broad use, with 5-10x lower compute infrastructure cost per byte scanned compared to traditional data privacy solutions. Its optimized infrastructure ensures low latency and high throughput for real-time AI applications handling large data volumes. Secure and flexible deployments within customers' VPCs or as isolated containers ensures data never leaves customer environments.\n\nResources\n\nSign up for Granica Screen on Google Cloud MarketplaceRead the Granica blogVisit the Granica websiteRequest a demoFollow Granica on X (formerly Twitter) and LinkedIn\n\nAbout Granica\n\nGranica is the training data platform for trusted AI. It makes AI safe, effective and efficient by optimizing the data sets used to train and fine-tune LLMs and other AI models, as well as optimizing model inference and RAG data. Granica's Safe Room for AI solution delivers privacy and safety for AI inputs and outputs, mitigating the risk of sensitive data leakage while also improving AI accuracy, performance and fairness. The result is increased trust in AI. Granica also makes tabular and NLP training data more efficient by physically optimizing cloud data lake files such as Apache Parquet to lower storage cost by up to 80% and improve query performance by up to 50%. Granica's training data services are easily consumed as an API by developers building AI applications. Granica is optimized for enterprises and technology companies in data and AI-intensive industries such as financial services, retail and ecommerce, geo-spatial intelligence, and autonomous vehicles. Category-defining companies including Quantum Metric, HERE Technologies, and Nylas use Granica to maximize innovation and business results from their data and AI initiatives.\n\nView source version on {"uri": "2024-07-433000063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "08:24:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T08:24:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T08:15:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://channelx.world/2024/07/fundamental-issues-threaten-the-ai-boom-says-odi/", "title": "Fundamental issues threaten the AI boom says ODI - ChannelX", "body": "The ODI's latest white paper, 'Building a better future with data and AI', is based on research carried out by the Institute in the first half of 2024. It identifies significant weaknesses in the UK's tech infrastructure that threaten the predicted potential gains - for people, society, and the economy - from the AI boom. It also outlines the ODI's recommendations for creating diverse, fair data-centric AI.\n\nBased on its research, the ODI is calling for the new government to take five actions that will allow the UK to benefit from the opportunities presented by AI while mitigating potential harms:\n\nThe ODI's white paper argues that the potential for emerging AI technologies to transform industries such as diagnostics and personalised education shows great promise. Yet significant challenges and risks are attached to widescale adoption, including - in the case of generative AI - reliance on a handful of machine learning datasets that ODI research has shown lack robust governance frameworks. This poses significant risks to both adoption and deployment, as inadequate data governance can lead to biases and unethical practices, undermining the trust and reliability of AI applications in critical areas such as healthcare, finance, and public services. These risks are exacerbated by a lack of transparency that is hampering efforts to address biases, remove harmful content, and ensure compliance with legal standards. To provide a clearer picture of how data transparency varies across different types of system providers, the ODI is developing a new 'AI data transparency index.'\n\nIf the UK is to benefit from the extraordinary opportunities presented by AI, the government must look beyond the hype and attend to the fundamentals of a robust data ecosystem built on sound governance and ethical foundations. We must build a trustworthy data infrastructure for AI because the feedstock of high-quality AI is high-quality data. The UK has the opportunity to build better data governance systems for AI that ensure we are best placed to take advantage of technological innovations and create economic and social value whilst guarding against potential risks.\n\nBefore the General Election, Labour's Manifesto outlined plans for a National Data Library to bring together existing research programmes and help deliver data-enabled public services. However, the ODI says that first, we need to ensure the data is AI-ready. As well as being accessible and trustworthy, data must meet agreed standards, which require a data assurance and quality assessment infrastructure. The ODI's recent research has found that currently - with a few exceptions - AI training datasets typically lack robust governance measures throughout the AI life cycle, posing safety, security, trust, and ethical challenges related to data protection and fair labour practices. Issues that needs to be addressed if the government is to make good on its plans.\n\nOther insights from the ODI's research include:", "source": {"uri": "channelx.world", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8242831354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:18:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:18:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:16:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://fashionunited.com/education/news/weaving-tradition-and-technology-ais-role-in-reshaping-fashion-in-asia/2024072561099", "title": "Weaving tradition and technology: AI's role in reshaping fashion in Asia", "body": "Asia's fashion creatives stand poised to flourish leveraging artificial intelligence. While AI has already begun to revolutionise aspects like trend forecasting, personalised recommendations, and supply chain efficiency, its potential within the creative heart of the industry -- design itself -- remains largely untapped. Some might fear AI replacing human artistry, but many see it as a powerful tool to augment creativity, allowing designers to explore new possibilities and push boundaries. This presents a unique opportunity for Asia's culturally-rich fashion scene to embrace AI and unlock a new era of innovation and expression.\n\nWhile AI can analyse existing data, it cannot truly have the inherent desire to \"wonder\" or question assumptions in the way humans do. AI struggles to grasp the nuances of human social interactions and cultural contexts, and cannot fully comprehend and respond to the emotional complexities that drive human creativity. This limits AI's ability to create fashion that moves people and resonates with human emotions and experiences. Instead of seeing AI as a threat, designers can view it as a powerful collaborator, freeing them from tedious tasks and allowing them to focus on the artistic aspects of their work.\n\nAsia's existing robust supply chain infrastructure, together with the up-and-coming boom in AI-related infrastructure such as data centres, will provide a solid foundation for integrating AI-powered solutions. AI will help build a seamless flow from design to production, such as creating realistic 3D models of garments, allowing for virtual fitting and adjustments, by taking a single clothing image and accurately reflecting how it would drape, fold, cling, stretch, and form wrinkles and shadows on a diverse set of real models in various poses.\n\nImplementing AI in the fashion industry requires a deep understanding of both fashion and artificial intelligence technologies. Skilled professionals are needed to develop, deploy, and maintain AI algorithms and systems tailored to the specific needs of the fashion sector.\n\nIt is prime time for fashion companies to jump on the bandwagon of innovation, as tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon, and Google are making a big push to invest and expand in Southeast Asia, which is home to 700 million people and whose economies are collectively worth over US$3.8 trillion. This shows that Asian countries are accelerating in attracting and nurturing AI talents. Coupled with the fact that Asia's \"Generation AI\" (those who have grown up with the technology), compared to other regions, is more ready than ever to learn and adopt new technologies, educators should leverage this opportune timing to prime the AI-ready workforce, and simultaneously foster closer collaboration between tech companies, brands, and academic institutions.\n\nEducators are crucial in fostering partnerships between tech companies, our own respective industry brands, and academic institutions. While Asia has significant investments in technology, there's a need for more focused R&D and education in AI specifically tailored to the fashion industry. We are already integrating AI into our curriculum through hands-on experiences like fabric pattern design and creating virtual fashion models, but a collaborative effort is still important because the process of developing proprietary AI tools that address the unique challenges and opportunities in Asian fashion requires wide partnership and devotion. By actively engaging with AI, we are in fact encouraging a more creative and responsible use of technology, preparing our future workforce for the AI era.\n\nThe most crucial thing to remember is that humans remain the ultimate decision-makers. AI-powered workflows serve as powerful tools that augment human intuition and creativity, allowing designers and manufacturers to make more informed and impactful decisions. AI-powered manufacturing processes free up human hands from repetitive tasks, allowing designers and craftspeople to focus their energy on the creative and strategic aspects of their work. By automating tasks like pattern cutting, fabric manipulation, and assembly, AI empowers humans to delve deeper into the realm of design concepts, material exploration, and innovative techniques. This shift from manual labour to creative thinking fosters a more fulfilling and impactful experience for those working in the fashion industry.\n\nAn example of the creative possibility could be tech-powered fashion crossovers showcasing Asia's diverse cultures. From the intricate silk saris of India to the flowing Hanfu of China, the region boasts a wealth of traditional garments with distinct styles, fabrics, and embroidery, inspiring contemporary designers to constantly reinterpret these traditional elements or blend them with modern trends to create exciting new aesthetics. Just as a Saudi designer has referenced traditional attire and invented his own futuristic style, Asia's deep and broad cultural pot presents a plethora of possibilities for bringing heritage into the future, waiting to be explored with AI. AI's role becomes evident in style transfers in these cross-cultural collaborations. Conveying the essence of one style onto another using AI, designers can create hybrid garments that blend elements from different cultures while promoting collaboration within the industry.\n\nThe influx of AI-powered solutions in fashion presents a unique opportunity for upskilling and reskilling existing workers. By investing in training programs that bridge the gap between traditional fashion expertise and AI knowledge, companies can empower their existing workforce to adapt to the changing landscape. This can involve training designers in AI-assisted design tools, teaching manufacturing workers to operate and maintain AI-powered machinery, and equipping sales and marketing professionals with data analysis and AI-driven personalization skills.\n\nThe future of fashion in Asia is bright, powered by the unique synergy of cultural inspiration, technological prowess, and a growing pool of talented creatives, yet it also requires fertile ground for us to see their fruition, including AI-savvy industry innovators and infrastructure support. By embracing AI, Asia's fashion industry can unlock a new era of innovation, where traditional aesthetics meet modern technology, and where designers push the boundaries of creativity. Through collaborative effort with fashion schools taking the lead to unite industry stakeholders, Asia's fashion creatives can flourish, not just by adapting to AI, but by shaping its future.",
