Today, thousands of exciting projects are being taken to production in all industries, while a report by Deloitte found that use of gen AI by employees at Australian workplaces rose to 38% in 2023. Despite the wide and fast adoption of AI, businesses across the region are struggling to keep up, trying to educate employees about the risks of AI and introducing secure applications provided by experienced technology vendors. If you're struggling with implementing AI in production, upskilling your workforce, or choosing trusted, secure solutions that respect compliance requirements, we're here to help. Our upcoming AI workshop in Sydney will help organisations navigate this challenging AI journey and accelerate their time to market.\n\nCanonical's promise to offer secure open software goes beyond Ubuntu and covers your entire stack, including AI tooling. We provide solutions to enable organisations to run their ML workloads at all scales, from workstations to cloud and edge devices. The company's experience of 20 years in the open source space is reflected in the AI industry, and is the reason we help organisations assess their AI readiness and build their ML infrastructure.\n\nAI readiness assessment\n\nAI has a huge potential to optimise costs, reduce manual tasks and enable innovation within any department. Organisations are put in front of a technological transformation that challenges them to restructure their entire infrastructure and reshape many of their processes. From optimising the compute power to introducing new tooling that enables machine learning operations (MLOps), they need to go through an entire journey before seeing any return on investment.\n\nAny AI initiative starts with initial experimentation on a workstation, which does not present a lot of problems. As projects progress, there is a need for more sophisticated tooling that can be used to automate ML workloads, optimise ML models and deploy them to edge devices. During the workshop, we will guide organisations in assessing their AI readiness and discuss how to build their architecture, depending on the use case or existing infrastructure.\n\nGenAI with open source tooling\n\nLinux Foundation reported in 2023 that almost half of the organisations prefer open source tooling for their GenAI projects. Open source lowers the barrier to entry, fosters collaboration and enables practitioners to experiment quickly. Despite this, enterprises still struggle because of security concerns, scalability of the ML tooling and costs associated with any GenAI initiatives.\n\nDuring the executive AI workshop in Sydney, I will talk about how open source enables GenAI projects. During the talk, I will focus on the key considerations and challenges that organisations face when moving GenAI projects from experimentation to production, as well as the common pitfalls that the industry faces. The talk will highlight open source tools such as OpenSearch and Kubeflow, that are used to productise GenAI initiatives and what are the security risks that they address. At the end of it, you will be better equipped to run your GenAI projects in production, using secure open source tooling.\n\nFuture of AI in Asia-Pacific\n\nHalfway through the year, we will take the proposed points and do a deep dive into the topic, focusing on the Asia-Pacific region. Together with industry leaders from Dell Technologies and Firmusgrid Supercloud Pty Ltd, we will discuss about the challenges that companies face when it comes to AI, industries that are ahead of time and the next big things that Australia will embrace\n\nThis event is by invitation only and tailored specifically for executive and senior management levels. Invitations will be sent out one month prior to the event to ensure a curated and impactful experience. Please register your interest to attend this exclusive workshop and join us in shaping the future of AI.", "source": {"uri": "ubuntu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Ubuntu"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8243280122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:05:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:05:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:05:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=78fdcdea-5580-4cc8-9323-7872917124a0", "title": "AI deployed for enhanced safety, predictive maintenance and air traffic flow", "body": "The aviation industry is no stranger to advanced systems that support, and at times replace, the need for human input. This notwithstanding, recent advancements in AI have had a profound impact across the industry; AI is being deployed to design more efficient airframes and engines, invent new composite materials, and to enhance safety, fuel efficiency and overall performance.\n\nIn the area of predictive maintenance, AI systems are able to analyse vast amounts of real time data from aircraft and engine sensors, combining this with its analysis of historical maintenance records to predict potential failures before they occur. This helps airlines to optimise their maintenance schedules and thus reduce downtime and improve fleet availability.\n\nIn air traffic management, AI optimises route planning, airspace operation, and traffic flow, allowing for more efficient use of airspace thus minimising delays, reducing fuel burn and emissions.\n\nIn and around airports, AI systems are deployed in a variety of scenarios too, from passport and security checks to baggage handling, as well as enhancing the passenger experience through a more bespoke and efficient service, leading to fewer delays. And for airports which can't employ enough staff to carry out day to day functions, an AI-led robotic approach is proving critical to enable them to sustain their operations.\n\nIt is clear that AI plays an important role in an often sensitive and high-risk environment, putting it front and centre of many new laws governing AI, including the EU AI Act. This is an increase of the compliance burden for companies operating in the aviation industry, on top of what is already a highly regulated sector.", "source": {"uri": "lexology.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243479918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:38:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:38:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:37:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/meganpoinski/2024/07/25/how-cios-can-go-from-ai-prototypes-to-deployment/", "title": "How CIOs Can Go From AI Prototypes To Deployment", "body": "This is the published version of Forbes' CIO newsletter, which offers the latest news for chief innovation officers and other technology-focused leaders. Click here to get it delivered to your inbox every Thursday.\n\nJust about everyone is using AI at work nowadays. According to a report this month from Netskope Threat Labs, 96% of offices are using some type of generative AI application. ChatGPT is far and away the most popular, with 80% of offices using it, but more than half are using Grammarly, Microsoft Copilot and Google Gemini.\n\nAcceptance and wide use of AI is just the first step, though. Employees have to be using it safely, not uploading proprietary data to open systems, and it's also important that all apps being used are worthy of trust. Netskope found that 77% of companies block at least one AI application, with the majority of those blocking 2.6 apps. More than a quarter -- 28% -- block presentation maker Beautiful.ai, but writing assistant Writesonic and image generator Craiyon are also blocked by more than a fifth of offices.\n\nThe constant proliferation of new AI apps, however, makes it difficult to protect your data just by blocking. More than 42% of companies are using sophisticated forms of data loss prevention. These involve things like blocking certain queries that may contain sensitive data, adding \"coaching\" interventions that make users stop and explain why they are trying to use an AI system in a certain way, and observing the kind of data that is pulled in large chunks from company data repositories. Netskope found these methods are largely effective. More than half of users stop the action they are trying to do when coaching prompts come up, the report found. However, the most common sensitive data uploaded to AI systems is source code, showing that the industry's focus on making AI coding apps is at least gaining steam.\n\nHowever, workplace AI applications are in a constant state of change. CIOs need to stay on top of both what is being used in their offices and up-and-coming AI trends, carefully evaluating the risks and rewards of different applications. And it may not get easier as generative AI becomes more common. After all, everyone is familiar with email, and yet security experts agree it's the top cybersecurity risk to companies today, mostly because of the way users interact with it.\n\nCompanies trying to create their own AI systems often run into problems after they build prototypes. While the prototype works well, it can be a challenge to translate it into a full system. I talked to Matthew Zeiler, cofounder and CEO of AI processes company Clarifai, about how to get past these issues. An excerpt from our conversation is later in this newsletter.\n\nIt's been an eventful week for Google. Cloud security startup Wiz walked away from a $23 billion acquisition offer from the tech giant, a deal that would have been Google's largest ever. The deal was buzzed about in tech circles after the Wall Street Journal reported earlier this month that the two were in advanced talks. Forbes senior editor Alex Konrad writes that Wiz CEO Assaf Rappaport sent a letter to employees outlining his company's next plans: Pursuing a $1 billion annual recurring revenue target, and then its own IPO. According to Bloomberg, this is the second big acquisition Google has been unable to complete this month; it also walked away from efforts to purchase HubSpot.\n\nThings did not improve when Google's parent company Alphabet reported earnings after markets closed on Tuesday. While its Q2 revenue of $84.2 billion beat analysts' estimates, its stock fell more than 5% when trading began on Wednesday. There were two big reasons behind the sell off. YouTube advertising missed analysts' estimates -- even though it actually increased 13% year-over-year. And Google's capital expenditures are also on the rise. The company is investing heavily in AI -- a likely total outlay of $49 billion in cap ex, which is 84% above its average over the last five years, reports the Wall Street Journal.\n\nGoogle, electric car maker Tesla, which reported slowing sales on Wednesday, and credit card company Visa, which also missed revenue goals, all brought the stock market as a whole down on Wednesday. The S&P 500 slid 2%, and the \"Magnificent Seven\" -- top tech stocks including Alphabet, Tesla, Nvidia, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft and Apple -- collectively lost $800 billion in value.\n\nMany companies are launching AI-powered applications, but in the rush to get in on the technology, it makes sense for executives and developers to pause and ensure they are solving the right problems. Employees say Target, which created \"Help AI\" as an internal chatbot providing knowledge about store processes, didn't take this maxim into consideration, Forbes senior writer Cyrus Farivar writes. The chatbot provides many wrong or misleading answers. Employees said it couldn't explain basic store terminology, refused to give tips about dealing with an impolite co-worker, and advised workers to confront an active shooter in the store with a weapon -- something the Department of Homeland Security explicitly advises against. A Target spokesperson told Forbes the retailer is open to feedback about the bot, but employees said the retailer focused on the wrong problems. An AI system that could help balance employee workloads, do a better job of tracking merchandise shipments, or find trends in services such as shopper pickup, they said, might actually help them.\n\nMuch of the modern world was literally brought to its knees last week after a glitch in a CrowdStrike update took millions of enterprise computer systems using Microsoft products offline. The outage impacted businesses including airlines, banks, media outlets and healthcare facilities. CrowdStrike and Microsoft pushed out a fix within hours, and the world slowly got back online. However, Delta Airlines seemed to experience the most problems, with thousands of flights canceled and delayed for days. On Tuesday, five days after the meltdown, 41% of Delta flights were still disrupted, Forbes' Suzanne Rowan Kelleher reported.\n\nOne major U.S. carrier saw zero issues: Southwest Airlines. Forbes senior contributor Ted Reed explains why: Major portions of Southwest's computer system are using Windows 3.1, the version of the operating system first launched in 1992. \"It's typically not a good idea to wait so long to update, but in this one instance Southwest has done itself a favor,\" Government Technology wrote.\n\nThis shouldn't be seen as a good reason to delay system updates, though. After all, a meltdown of outdated tech used for crew scheduling following massive blizzards led to Southwest canceling 16,900 flights and stranding more than 2 million passengers over the Christmas holiday in 2022. Southwest had to pay more than $600 million in customer refunds and reimbursements, and the U.S. Department of Transportation socked the airline with a $140 million civil penalty.\n\nIt's easy to come up with a working prototype for an AI solution at your company. It's much harder to turn that idea into a deployed system. Clarifai, a company that specializes in streamlining processes for AI, recently published a report about AI sprawl -- when the use cases for a system push beyond their original scope -- and how it adds more problems to the already challenging development cycle. Founder and CEO Matthew Zeiler talked to me about the issues many companies face in their development and how to solve them. This conversation has been edited for length, clarity and continuity.\n\nA lot of companies that are working on AI say, 'We've got a great prototype. It works well, but it's been a long time and we haven't been able to get the full version working.' What's usually the hangup between the prototype and the actual deployment?\n\nZeiler: That's what we have coined the false finish line. People can quickly get running on a laptop. There's a bunch of tools that either are open source or provided by companies that help you stitch together stuff, but at the end of the day, those are really just API clients. They're very surface-level integrations.\n\nWhen you think of getting to production, it means is this thing trustable in front of your customers? Is it going to stay up 24/7? Is it going to autoscale when your traffic changes? Are you going to have feedback loops so that when your data changes, your models are still going to remain accurate? Are you evaluating the accuracy of your models on your real world data? Or is just, 'It works in one example in my prototype, so it works for good'?\n\nThat's unrealistic. There's all those considerations that are preventing people from going from prototype to production. The timelines become many months to years, depending on your application and how many applications you want to get into production.\n\nHow does anybody get past the false finish line?\n\nYou have two choices. You could stitch together a bunch of different tools. At every layer you could choose from third party vendors, open source tools. It becomes a daunting task that you need AI expertise to even navigate. You have to stitch it together, write tests, which you're probably not going to do. It can take you a lot of time to make these tools work together. You have to keep them up to date and state-of-the-art. It's a very brittle system. If any of the platforms go down or their APIs change or whatever, everything breaks. We've seen that firsthand. The whole program can stall for weeks at a time.\n\nThat's the technology side. Another aspect is streamlining just the processes, procuring all the different tools, reviewing legal terms, reviewing security, trying to understand where your data may live.\n\n[A company that deals with AI architecture can] help you streamline that. So those are the two choices. Go with the AI workflow orchestration approach, or stitch it all together yourself.\n\nWhat advice would you give to a CIO trying to go from AI prototype to deployment?\n\n[Ask yourself] what business problem are you trying to solve, and what do you expect AI to do? Is AI even the right tool for that problem? More and more, it is the right tool. Once you understand the problem, then start to think about how you're going to solve that. And that's where five different layers of consideration come in. The two AI-specific layers are the model and data considerations. What model are you going to use? What does the model need to do?\n\nGetting your data to be AI ready is really, really important. That's going to be the first thing that's going to block you, because you won't be able to get a model to work well on your specific data until your data's in order.\n\nThe remaining three layers are where you want to go from that prototype to actual production. Do you have the compute to process all these workloads? Is it going to be secure? When you're thinking about your vendor stack and your use case, that could mean very different things. We work with the intelligence community on top secret networks, and they have to deploy our stack on-premise, disconnected from the internet. Security for them is very different than a mobile app that can connect to the internet. And then the control layer really becomes important for those Day 2 operations and large-scale enterprise multi-use case, preventing the AI sprawl problem.\n\nStartup Cloverleaf Infrastructure closed a funding round last week to deliver shovel-ready sites for the construction of hyperscale data centers with access to enough power to handle AI queries.\n\n$300 million: Amount the startup raised from Sandbrook Capital and NGP\n\n9%: Proportion of U.S. electricity that data centers are expected to use by 2030, up from 4% today\n\n'This is a complex power orchestration problem': Cloverleaf cofounder Brian Janous said\n\nComputer science spans a wealth of topics, from the widely used to the obscure. These five concepts are less known, but could result in new innovations.\n\nIt's been assumed employees will not want to embrace AI for fear it will take their jobs. Surveys show this is not the case, and they are excited for the benefits it can bring.\n\nThere are currently 10,000 functioning satellites orbiting Earth, estimates Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics astronomer Jonathan McDowell. Which entity controls the majority of them?", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242908024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:03:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:03:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:02:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://news.crunchbase.com/ai/regulation-microsoft-openai-inflection-legal-tech-clio-harvey/", "title": "Eye On AI: Microsoft Continues To Try To Tiptoe Around Regulation", "body": "This column is a look back at the week that was in AI. Read the previous one here.\n\nIt certainly has been a busy period for the news cycle, so it's understandable you may have missed some stuff in the past few days.\n\nThat includes a couple of things that involve perhaps the biggest name in AI -- Microsoft.\n\nA week later, it was announced that the company's unusual relationship with generative AI startup Inflection AI would be referred for an initial merger investigation in the U.K.\n\nThat's funny, because Microsoft went to great lengths to frame its deal with Inflection as anything but an acquisition -- rather it just hired the startup's co-founders, most of its 70-person staff, and licensed its technology.\n\nBut it wasn't an acquisition.\n\nThe initial investigation will last through the summer, and there's no telling how it will play out. Microsoft scored a win of sorts in June when the EU Commission said it was dropping its probe into the company's relationship with OpenAI.\n\nHowever, it does seem Microsoft is playing with fire. There appears to be an announcement every month about some agency -- foreign or domestic -- looking into its AI dealings. Jumping off OpenAI's board seemed to be a move -- albeit very small -- by two AI giants to try to avoid more antitrust scrutiny.\n\nThe Inflection AI deal seemed to be screaming for that scrutiny and now it seems like it'll be getting it.\n\nThere is no doubt of Microsoft's intense interest in the space. Its venture arm, M12 just led a $40 million round for San Francisco-based Armada, which helps with the implementation of artificial intelligence in an edge computing environment.\n\nNevertheless, Microsoft may be getting closer to real problems with every AI deal it consummates. While AI holds the promise of reducing -- or even eliminating -- the workload for a lot of people, it seems like it will only increase it for the Microsoft legal team.\n\nJust a month ago we wrote about AI's impact on the legal tech industry, and this week provided a perfect illustration with not one, but two huge raises.\n\nOn Tuesday, Vancouver-based legal tools platform Clio raised a big $900 million Series F at a $3 billion valuation led by New Enterprise Associates. On the same day, San Francisco-based artificial intelligence startup Harvey raised a $100 million Series C led by GV with participation from the likes of OpenAI, Kleiner Perkins and Sequoia Capital at a $1.5 billion valuation. (Slightly less than the previously reported $600 million at a $2 billion valuation the startup was said to have been looking for.)\n\nThe two rounds alone make up for nearly two-thirds of the $1.6 billion the legal tech industry has raised in venture this year, per Crunchbase data. It also means legal tech funding has nearly doubled from the $877 million it raised all of last year.\n\nAI is having a lot to do with that, as AI startups are catering to the legal world -- traditional slow adopters of tech -- to help with mundane and routine tasks involving things like legal discovery and client management.\n\nWhile venture funding remains slightly rocky, legal tech is cleaning up thanks to AI.", "source": {"uri": "news.crunchbase.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Crunchbase News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_metinko@news.crunchbase.com", "name": "Chris Metinko", But the real test will be if the tech can make their firms more money.", "body": "Hello! The iPhone could reportedly get a major redesign to turn it into a...flip phone. What year are we living in?\n\nIn today's big story, dozens of Wall Street employees open up about how they are (or aren't) using AI on the job.\n\nWhat's on deck:\n\nMarkets: What a second Trump term would mean for the deficit, inflation, and yields. Tech: Some early-stage founders have reevaluated their startup dreams, opting for corporate life instead. Business: The best bet for fixing your love life might be the government. (It's not as weird as it sounds.)\n\nBut first, I got a tool for that.\n\nIf this was forwarded to you, sign up here.\n\nThe big story AI pulse check on Wall Street\n\n\"How are you using generative AI?\"\n\nThe question has dominated the business world for almost two years. Once ChatGPT graced us with its presence, everyone wanted to know how to leverage the tech to get ahead.\n\nWall Street, with its reams of data and need to analyze complex topics, has always been viewed as fertile ground for the AI revolution. So Business Insider's finance team spoke with almost three dozen finance workers across the industry about how they're using AI.\n\nFrom helping to identify startups to invest in to aggregating thousands of analyst notes to cutting down the time spent on busy work, AI use cases on the Street ran the gamut.\n\nOverall, generative AI typically helped finance professionals do their jobs faster, easier, or both.\n\nNot everyone is sold. Some don't see the \"breakthrough\" possibilities of the tech that so many have prophesied, finding it hard to see specific uses of AI in their own processes.\n\nAnd to be fair, they might not be wrong. As much as Wall Street likes to tout tech adoption, certain corners remain unchanged from decades ago, albeit with a few extra bells and whistles.\n\nNot unlike the workers it's looking to serve, gen AI's future on Wall Street will boil down to its ability to produce results.\n\nAI development doesn't come cheap. Whether you're starting from scratch or buying something off the shelf, there's plenty of costs to consider, from talent to hardware to retraining staff.\n\nBlackstone expects the US to spend roughly $1 trillion over the next five years building and facilitating new data centers that'll help power the gen AI wave.\n\nThat kind of cash means investors will want to see real changes in how things are done thanks to AI. It's a question Big Tech leaders are already fielding.\n\nOn Tuesday, Alphabet executives were pressed on whether Google's AI overview feature was generating more revenue for the firm, writes BI's Katherine Tangalakis-Lippert. And Nvidia has plans to show how its customers are making money using its AI chips when it reports earnings next month.\n\nThey won't be alone, as Goldman expects the market to keenly watch if AI spend can translate to revenue.\n\nAnd that's in tech where companies are supposed to take big swings on innovative projects! Now consider Wall Street, where ROI is built into the core of the industry.\n\nWill those firms continue pouring money into tech that can't improve their bottom line? In the end, finance workers' views on using generative AI, whatever they are, might not matter.\n\n3 things in markets How the markets are pricing in a Trump win. With prediction markets favoring former President Donald Trump winning in November, the markets are reacting accordingly. Here's how the deficit, inflation, and yields would be impacted by Trump's potential return to the White House. Why the (market) party can keep going. Bank of America pointed to narrow junk-bond spreads and $6 trillion in cash as bullish indicators the market rally will continue. Even smaller-cap stocks enjoying a surge is a sign of a \"broadening of the rally,\" BofA technical analyst Stephen Suttmeier said. Small-cap stocks to buy for big gains amid rally. Historically cheap small-cap stocks are roaring back to life during a risky earnings season. But not all are in the clear, a small-cap strategist at Bank of America warned. Here are 9 stocks in sectors that should outperform. 3 things in tech Founders' dreams on hold. Amid the collapse of some 3,200 venture-backed startups this year, some early-stage founders are testing out life as corporate employees for a break. Despite the better quality of life in corporate jobs, most want to someday be founders again. \"This is our golf course.\" A Hamptons retreat for female founders includes free-flowing ros\u00e9, a freebie bin of Larroud\u00e9 sandals, and a speaker lineup that includes \"Sex and the City\" author Candace Bushnell. It's the rare sanctuary where women in business connect without men in the room. Mark Zuckerberg's brat summer. Hot Zuck Summer is in full swing, both personally and professionally for the Meta founder. He won high praise for open-sourcing Meta's AI model, Llama 3.1, which he's been promoting. He also debuted a summer glow with a goggle-shaped tan line around his eyes -- though he said it's not a hint about Meta's Orion AR project. 3 things in business Make America date again. Dating apps are so bad that young people are giving up on them altogether. Could a government-run matchmaking service be the answer to our loneliness epidemic. Group Black was supposed to even the playing field for Black-owned media. Instead, its momentum fizzled. Former staff and people close to the company blame its struggles on advertisers' broken pledges, internal disorganization, and execution stumbles. They're left wondering what its future holds. Are your credit card rewards making you a jerk? Companies love rewards, and cardholders do, too. But when everyone at group dinner is rushing to put their card down first, the struggle over who gets the points can get ugly real fast. {"uri": "2024-07-433372679", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:47:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:47:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:00:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/marchex-receives-ai-breakthrough-award-for-best-text-generative-ai-solution-for-its-call-summaries/article_75126b96-c19b-5ebc-a6be-30c7677f0299.html", "title": "Marchex Receives AI Breakthrough Award for \"Best Text Generative AI Solution\" for its Call Summaries and Sentiment Suite", "body": "SEATTLE--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Jul 25, 2024--\n\nMarchex (NASDAQ: MCHX), which harnesses the power of AI and conversational intelligence to drive operational excellence and revenue acceleration, today announced that Marchex Call Summaries and Sentiment Suite have collectively been chosen as the \"Best Text Generative AI Solution\" in the seventh annual AI Breakthrough Awards program conducted by AI Breakthrough, a leading market intelligence organization that recognizes the top companies, technologies, and products in today's global AI marketplace. This year's program attracted more than 5,000 nominations from around the world. 2024 is the third consecutive year Marchex has been selected for an AI Breakthrough Award.\n\nThe mission of the AI Breakthrough Awards is to honor excellence and recognize innovation, hard work, and success in a range of AI and machine learning-related categories including Generative AI, Computer Vision, AIOps, Deep Learning, Robotics, Natural Language Processing, industry-specific AI applications, and many more.\n\nAs a leader in AI, the Marchex Call Summaries and Sentiment Suite analyzes and generates summaries of consumer-to-business calls, enabling businesses to immediately identify customers who have had exceptionally good or bad experiences with the business. This valuable data empowers companies to capitalize on interactions by advancing sales processes, encouraging positive online behaviors (including reviews), or taking action to rectify concerns from dissatisfied customers.\n\nCall Summaries ensure that organizations no longer need to listen to every phone call to understand the essential conversations that are taking place. This capability provides two distinct types of summaries:\n\nOutcome Focused Summaries that deliver concise, natural-language descriptions of what occurred during a consumer-to-business call.Agent Focused Summaries that provide comprehensive assessments of customer service or sales agent performance during calls.\n\nSentiment Suite is one of the innovative applications that sets Marchex apart. The company combines structured and unstructured data to provide a holistic view of customer emotions during conversations and the reason why someone feels the way they do:\n\nEmotion Categories assign specific sentiments (such as satisfied, frustrated, or confused) to callers, enabling tailored response strategies.Customer Emotion provides a high-level assessment of whether conversations were positive, negative, or neutral.View of Business combines emotion grading and call context to infer how the customer perceives your business.\n\n\"Understanding consumer-to-business conversations in a way that can improve the sales process is a game-changer for many vertical industries, enabling businesses to capitalize on consumer data,\" said James Johnson, managing director, AI Breakthrough. \"Congratulations to Marchex for earning a third consecutive AI Breakthrough Award. Their expertise, experience, and flexible platform empower businesses to glean insights that measurably improve their customers' experience and their own bottom lines.\"\n\n\"We are honored to receive this year's AI Breakthrough Award, a testament to our team's dedication in pioneering AI-powered technologies and solutions. This recognition underscores our focus on delivering innovative solutions that drive operational excellence and market expansion for our clients,\" said Edwin Miller, CEO of Marchex. \"As we continue to introduce new and advanced conversational intelligence and data analytics capabilities, we are committed to providing actionable insights that can transform businesses and accelerate revenue growth.\"\n\nPlease visit http://www.marchex.com,www.marchex.com/blog or @marchex on X ( Twitter.com/Marchex ), where Marchex discloses material information from time to time about the company, its financial information, and its business.\n\nAbout AI Breakthrough\n\nPart of Tech Breakthrough, a leading market intelligence and recognition platform for global technology innovation and leadership, the AI Breakthrough Awards program is devoted to honoring excellence in artificial intelligence technologies, services, companies and products. The AI Breakthrough Awards provide public recognition for the achievements of AI companies and products in categories including AI Platforms, Robotics, Business Intelligence, AI Hardware, NLP, Computer Vision and more. For more information visit AIBreakthroughAwards.com.\n\nAbout Marchex\n\nMarchex harnesses the power of AI and omnichannel conversational intelligence to provide actionable insights aligned with prescriptive vertical market data analytics, driving operational excellence and revenue acceleration. Marchex enables executive, sales, and marketing teams to optimize customer journey experiences across communications channels. Through our prescriptive analytics solutions, we enable the alignment of enterprise strategy, empowering businesses to increase revenue through informed decision-making and strategic execution. Marchex provides conversational intelligence AI-powered solutions for market-leading companies in leading B2B2C vertical markets, including several of the world's most innovative and successful brands.\n\nView source version on businesswire.com:https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20240725413134/en/\n\nCONTACT: Marchex, Inc.\n\nInvestor Relations\n\nTrevor Caldwell, Here's how it's impacting business and academia.", "body": "For decades, the field of artificial intelligence seemed stagnant. Researchers started gaining momentum in the early 2010s as deep learning proved useful in real-world applications such as speech recognition. The real inflection point, however, did not come until November 2022, when OpenAI launched ChatGPT.\n\nThe chatbot represented a huge leap in AI's capabilities. The ability to build intelligent systems out of computer chips, a goal that seemed decades away, now seems within reach. ChatGPT's advanced natural language processing abilities showcased the potential for AI to comprehend and generate human-like text, proving to be a versatile tool for a plethora of applications from customer service to content creation.\n\nThis technology has drastically changed the field of AI, driving activity in both the private sector and academia. Major technology companies and startups are investing heavily in AI development, creating a competitive landscape in the field. Universities are also ramping up their AI research programs to keep pace with industry advancements. According to the 2024 Stanford AI Index Report, this frenzy is reshaping industries through a surge in startup formation and accelerated research efforts.\n\nVerbit analyzed Stanford's AI Index Report to better understand how AI has changed in recent years and highlighted the exponential growth in AI-related publications and patents.\n\nVisit thestacker.com for similar lists and stories.", At the Republican Party convention on July 19, the presidential candidate referred to this technology in a passage of his speech devoted to the \"new golden age\" he hopes to bring about - and which \"all other countries,\" including China and Japan, are also seeking to achieve. \"We have to produce massive amounts of energy (...). But AI needs tremendous - literally, twice the electricity that's available now in our country, can you imagine?\" he warned, without mentioning the environmental consequences of such an energy boom.\n\nFor the former US president, AI development seems primarily to involve the deregulation of the sector. The Republican Party platform therefore promises to \"repeal Joe Biden's dangerous Executive Order that hinders AI Innovation, and imposes Radical Leftwing ideas on the development of this technology.\"\n\nAdopted in October 2023, this presidential text aimed to \"protect Americans from the potential risks of AI systems\" by requiring, under the supervision of federal agencies, software manufacturers to conduct tests to ensure that they are \"safe, secure and trustworthy,\" to avoid breaches of national security, cyber-attacks, but also manipulation or algorithmic bias and discrimination.\n\nAt a recent hearing on AI and privacy, Senator J. D. Vance, Trump's vice presidential pick, extended this hostility to AI regulation: \"Very often CEOs, especially of larger technology companies that I think already have advantageous positions in AI will come and talk about the terrible safety dangers of this new technology and how Congress needs to jump up and regulate as quickly as possible. And I can't help but worry that if we do something under duress from the current incumbents, it's going to be to the advantage of those incumbents and not to the advantage of the American consumer.\"\n\nOn X, he added that, in his opinion, \"a partisan group of crazy people use AI to infect every part of the information economy with left-wing bias.\" This argument is reminiscent of Trump's criticism of social media and joins Elon Musk's attacks on OpenAI or Google, accused of censoring free speech through moderation measures put in place to prevent their chatbots from broadcasting discriminatory responses or hate speech. The Tesla and X boss, now a Trump supporter and generous donor, launched GrokAI with the idea of it being, in contrast, an \"anti-woke\" chatbot.", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243502251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:58:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:58:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:56:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/sarah-novotny-joins-genlab-studio-to-pioneer-ai-and-autonomous-systems-innovations/article_eef8c065-b5c9-5d9c-a96c-2ecbc69b211d.html", "title": "Sarah Novotny Joins GenLab Studio to Pioneer AI and Autonomous Systems Innovations", "body": "SAN FRANCISCO--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Jul 25, 2024--\n\nGenLab Studio announces that Sarah Novotny has joined the team as Chief Technology Officer and Partner to lead groundbreaking products for autonomous systems and artificial intelligence. Sarah's first initiative will focus on AI security, with a new effort just launched, Coalition for Secure AI, hosted by OASIS Open, a nonprofit consortium known for fostering open standards for the global information society.\n\nSarah's background in leading cross-industry open-source collaborations will be critical to building secure, scalable products within critical infrastructure. Previously at Google and Microsoft, her understanding of the complexity of global AI ecosystems will create sustaining value in GenLab companies.\n\nA veteran of the Kubernetes, OpenTelemetry, and Node.js communities, she will drive GenLab's talent, community, and technology.\n\nSarah will spearhead GenLab's participation in the Coalition for Secure AI (CoSAI), a collaboration designed to tackle the growing need for robust security measures in AI systems. As AI becomes more prevalent in autonomous systems -- the physical manifestation of AI -- and other critical applications, enhancing threat mitigation strategies is essential to secure AI ecosystems.\n\n\"Our partnership with OASIS Open is crucial as it aligns with our goals of enhancing AI security,\" said Sarah Novotny. \"This collaboration will drive the creation of superior products that deliver higher revenue and value to our stakeholders.\"\n\nGenLab Studio is committed to building the strongest infrastructures for future technologies. This includes focusing on data sovereignty ensuring that data is managed, controlled, and protected according to stringent security practices.\n\n\"Generative AI solutions are inherently complex, and integrating them seamlessly into existing frameworks demands exceptional talent,\" Sarah added. \"My experience and expertise will help streamline the integration of these advanced systems, ensuring they deliver significant value and innovation.\"\n\nSarah noted, \"By leveraging OASIS Open's expertise in setting standards, we are fostering an innovative and cross-diverse community dedicated to developing groundbreaking solutions. Collaborative efforts in AI security research, tooling development, and best practice sharing will underpin GenLab Studio's mission to revolutionize the AI and autonomous systems sectors.\"\n\nAbout GenLab Studio\n\nGenLab Studio is a venture studio building startups that leverage the impact and application of generative AI. By focusing on solid design principles and engaging a diverse community, GenLab Studio aims to create groundbreaking products that help build a stronger ecosystem for AI.\n\nView source version on {"uri": "8242722560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "09:10:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T09:10:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T09:09:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://coingeek.com/india-lack-of-quality-data-ai-infrastructure-pose-hurdles-in-mitigating-climate-change-experts/", "title": "India's lack of quality data, AI infrastructure pose hurdles in mitigating climate change: experts", "body": "India has started using artificial intelligence (AI) to mitigate climate change risks but has a long way to go as economic constraints, bureaucratic hurdles, and socio-political factors decelerate implementation.\n\n\"India is not using AI extensively to address climate change risks primarily due to factors such as limited infrastructure, lack of data availability, insufficient skilled workforce in AI and environmental sciences, and the high cost of implementing advanced AI technologies,\" Rohan Sharan, founder and chief executive of Timechain Labs, an on-chain application development firm utilizing BSV blockchain technology, told CoinGeek.\n\n\"The most critical challenges include inadequate infrastructure, lack of financial resources, poor policy implementation, and limited public awareness,\" Sharan added.\n\nIndia is feeling the ill effects of climate change with rising temperatures and heat waves, erratic monsoons and devastating floods. In 2023, India suffered extreme weather events almost daily during the first nine months of the year, killing 2,923 people and affecting close to 1.84 million hectares of crop area.\n\nEarlier this month, increased heat generation due to climate change led to more thunderstorms and lightning strikes, killing at least 64 people in the northern Indian states of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. The people killed were either transplanting paddy in fields, grazing cattle, or taking shelter under trees to protect themselves from rain.\n\n\"Addressing climate change with AI is a long-term commitment requiring sustained investment and consistent policies, which are not yet on the horizon,\" said Raj Kapoor, chairman of Global Alliance for Ethical AI Innovation.\n\n\"The inherent biases of AI models training data may often lead to unfair outcomes that disproportionately affect certain communities. In India, these are sensitive issues. Add to that the opacity of AI decision-making processes, lack of transparency, [making] it difficult for stakeholders to trust these systems,\" Kapoor added.\n\nLack of high-quality, comprehensive data is often unavailable or inconsistent, especially in remote areas. AI models also require high accuracy and reliability to predict complex climate systems effectively. Integrating AI with existing climate monitoring systems is a complex process, and scaling these models to handle global data continues to be a major hurdle.\n\nIn March, the government approved $1.24 billion for the next five years to boost the country's AI ecosystem, innovation and entrepreneurship. The initiative is expected to boost the country's global leadership in AI and ensure ethical and responsible AI deployment.\n\n\"The required infrastructure for AI, such as data centres, demands substantial investment and may not be feasible in all regions. India, with its diverse demography, will face these challenges,\" Kapoor pointed out. \"The global nature of climate change necessitates international coordination, which is challenging due to varying policies and priorities. Allocating adequate funding and ensuring efficient resource allocation are persistent issues. The need for interdisciplinary collaboration across climate science, data science, engineering, and social sciences, are often difficult to coordinate.\"\n\nMoreover, the production and disposal of AI hardware contribute to e-waste and resource depletion, and India is yet to find an optimal resolution to address this.\n\n\"India's policy framework for climate adaptation, while comprehensive, often suffers from inadequate implementation at the local level due to fragmented governance, lack of coordination among agencies, and insufficient capacity and resources,\" Kapoor stated.\n\n\"While India has committed substantial funds for climate action, the scale of the challenge necessitates much higher investment. Mobilising financial resources for large-scale adaptation projects, particularly in a developing country context, is challenging. That is further compounded by the need for technological advancements and infrastructure development, which require substantial initial investments and long-term maintenance,\" Kapoor added.\n\nThe plans\n\nEarlier this month, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar said that the country is working towards achieving a reduction in emissions and building climate-resilient infrastructure.\n\nIn June, Abhay Karandikar, secretary of the Department of Science and Technology (DST), said that DST's two missions -- the National Mission for Sustaining Himalayan Ecosystem (NMSHE) and the National Mission on Strategic Knowledge for Climate Change (NMSKCC) -- have led to significant progress in supporting 19 centers of excellence and 37 major research and development programs over the years.\n\n\"I believe that we may need to focus more on developing foundational models in AI in the Indian context,\" Karandikar said. He pointed out that indigenous climate models based on data would bring about a better understanding of addressing climate change.\n\n\"Collective efforts towards a holistic approach involving researchers from multiple disciplines and a range of stakeholders can help address ongoing challenges of climate change and its effect on agriculture, water and environment,\" Karandikar said.\n\nIn March, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in a conversation with Bill Gates, called for redefining economic growth parameters to prioritise concepts like green GDP (gross domestic product), green income and green employment.\n\nModi said he is introducing a clean hydrogen boat to support the Clean Ganga movement, a project aimed at effectively abatement of pollution, conservation and rejuvenation of the National River Ganga.\n\n\"Reuse and recycle is in the nature of Indians,\" Modi told Gates. \"It doesn't matter how much external effort we put in or innovations we do; if we don't embrace a lifestyle that respects nature, it is not going to work. The goal should be to evaluate environment-friendly and climate-friendly innovations. India's Mission Life urges people to take action towards environmental protection and conservation.\"\n\nInterestingly, in its Mission Life initiative, the government said that the country's per capita carbon footprint is 60% lower than the global average because the country's lifestyle is still rooted in sustainable traditional practices as sustainability has always been a part of India's tradition, culture and values.\n\n\"Using AI can lead to significant cost savings by optimizing resource usage, reducing waste, improving energy efficiency, and preventing environmental disasters through early detection and intervention. This can also stimulate economic growth by creating new job opportunities and fostering innovation in green technologies,\" Sharan said.\n\n\"India can make the best use of AI by developing robust data collection systems, investing in AI research specific to environmental applications, promoting public-private partnerships for AI innovation, and integrating AI tools in policy-making for efficient resource management, early warning systems, and monitoring environmental changes,\" Sharan added.\n\nClimate change and AI in agriculture\n\nIndia, the world's largest democracy with 1.4 billion people, is primarily an agrarian economy, with about 55% of the total workforce engaged in agricultural and allied sector activities. The South Asian nation is one of the world's biggest producers of rice, wheat and sugar, making accurate weather forecasting extremely significant. The Asian powerhouse is also the world's second-largest tea producer, after China, and has suffered crop loss and reduced productivity due to drought and changing rainfall patterns caused by climate change.\n\nIndia's agrarian economy is highly susceptible to climatic variations, jeopardizing food security and livelihoods, particularly in rural areas, due to erratic rainfall patterns and extreme weather conditions. Moreover, depleting groundwater and inefficient water management practices lead to water scarcity, significantly affecting agricultural activities.\n\nAccording to a PwC study, the integration of AI into agriculture has led to the emergence of \"precision agriculture,\" where AI plays a more prescriptive role in emission reduction. Also known as \"smart farming,\" precision agriculture seeks to enhance productivity, improve agricultural yields and reduce resource consumption with the guidance of AI.\n\nFor instance, precision fertilizer applications utilize sensors, software, and application hardware to monitor and analyze real-time conditions of crops, soil, and other indicators of crop growth. Automated systems, built upon AI techniques, then adjust the rate of fertilizer applications to optimal levels, decreasing waste and the environmental footprint of fertiliser use.\n\nAccording to the PwC report, one such application is Alternate Wetting and Drying (AWD), a method of optimized irrigation to minimize water-intensive overflooding of rice fields.\n\n\"Aided by Terrascope's AI-enabled carbon management platform, a programme that implemented AWD for 700 rice farms in Northern India reported 48% reduction in methane emissions, 20% reduction in costs and 12% jump in harvest. AI levers can thus help to guide decisions and actions around decarbonisation more effectively,\" the PwC stated in its study.\n\nInterestingly, the World Economic Forum India's Centre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, in collaboration with India's Union Ministry of Agriculture and the Indian state of Telangana, has introduced the AI4AI initiative (AI for Agriculture Innovation). Over eight months beginning June 2020, this initiative held over 45 workshops, to discuss the challenges smallholder farmers face. These discussions led to an AI4AI plan that helped smallholder farmers by harnessing the power of new technologies, including AI, blockchain and drones.\n\nThe AI4AI framework was tested among 7,000 farmers in the Khammam district of Telangana. The pilot took 18 months and three crop cycles to complete. During this time, farmers reported a significant surge in net income -- $800 per acre in a single crop cycle (six months) -- effectively doubling the average income. The digital advisory services contributed to a 21% increase in chili yield production per acre. Pesticide use fell by 9%, fertilizers dropped by 5%, and quality improvements boosted unit prices by 8%. As a result, in October 2023, the state government expanded the Saagu Baagu initiative to include 500,000 farmers, covering five crops across 10 districts.\n\nAI for accurate weather prediction\n\nSo far, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has announced plans to use AI and machine learning to predict weather conditions and has reportedly put together a network of 39 doppler weather radars covering 85% of India's landmass that allow hourly forecasts for major cities.\n\n\"We have started using artificial intelligence in a limited way, but within the next five years, AI will significantly enhance our models and techniques,\" IMD's director general, Mrutyunjay Mohapatra, said in April.\n\n\"Incorporating AI and machine learning allows us to harness past data to extract valuable insights and improve forecasting accuracy without solely relying on traditional physics-based models,\" Mohapatra added.\n\nAI and machine learning (ML) techniques are also being used to improve weather, climate, and ocean forecast prediction at various institutes under the Ministry of Earth Sciences (MoES). MoES said it envisages that many weather and climate forecasts will be based on hybrid technology combining AI, ML models and traditional numerical weather prediction models. MoES said it is committed to enhance the High-Performance Computing (HPC) infrastructure as well. AI and ML-based data-driven modeling is required for generating species-specific Potential Fishing Zone (PFZ) advisories for fishermen across the coastal states in India.\n\n\"The first thing we need to do is to leverage predictive analytics for accurate weather and climate forecasting, optimising renewable energy production and grid management, and implementing precision agriculture to enhance crop yields and water usage efficiency,\" Kapoor said.\n\n\"With AI monitoring air and water quality in real-time, timely pollution control measures can be addressed. AI can optimise the generation and distribution of renewable energy. By predicting energy production from solar and wind sources and managing grid stability, AI will streamline the use of renewable resources and reduce reliance on fossil fuels. Finally, the ability of AI to analyse large datasets will place the spotlight on effective environmental policy-making,\" Kapoor added.\n\nIndia said it is committed to achieving the Net Zero emissions target by 2070 and is considering implementing the \"Lifestyle for Environment Mission\" (LiFE) initiative and promoting AI for achieving sustainable development goals (SDGs).\n\nWork in progress\n\nIndia's largest information technology service provider, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), has introduced an AI, ML, and analytics-powered solution that aims to meet city and business demands while complying with eco-friendly protocols and regulations.\n\n\"Cities and enterprises today are on a journey to become operationally interconnected, resilient, and sustainable as they work to balance responsible growth and climate strategies,\" TCS said.\n\n\"TCS Intelligent Urban Exchange (IUX) for intelligent climate action is an advanced AI and ML-powered decisioning sustainability solution that delivers comprehensive insights, recommendations, and metrics for environmentally responsible city, enterprise, and value chain operations,\" the company stated.\n\nOn the other hand, two local non-profit organizations, Gujarat Mahila Housing Sewa Trust and Villgro Innovation Foundation, are reportedly leveraging AI, ML, and the Internet of Things (IoT) to tackle the threats of water scarcity and flooding in India.\n\nGujarat Mahila Housing Sewa Trust aims to build an AI-based model to improve climate resilience in Amalner town in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. The model is expected to act as a blueprint for similar small urban towns in India, and provide them with an effective framework to reduce the risks of climate change and build resilience to natural disasters.\n\n\"Disaster preparedness through AI-powered early warning systems and risk assessments mitigates the economic impact of natural disasters, reducing costs associated with recovery and rebuilding. AI also facilitates compliance with environmental regulations by monitoring emissions in real-time and automating reporting, thus avoiding fines and reducing manual compliance costs,\" Kapoor added.\n\nIn order for artificial intelligence (AI) to work right within the law and thrive in the face of growing challenges, it needs to integrate an enterprise blockchain system that ensures data input quality and ownership -- allowing it to keep data safe while also guaranteeing the immutability of data. Check out CoinGeek's coverage on this emerging tech to learn more why Enterprise blockchain will be the backbone of AI.\n\nWatch: Exploring use cases for blockchain in India", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243198427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:09:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:09:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:09:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.rocketnews.com/2024/07/how-hellogov-is-bringing-vertically-integrated-ai-into-the-government-space/", "title": "How HelloGov is bringing vertically-integrated AI into the government space - RocketNews", "body": "While headlines continue to be dominated by the evolution of LLMs and their various new products, AI is entering its next phase: industry-specific applications of cutting-edge AI technology to disrupt and innovate in industries typically defined by slow or out-of-date practices.\n\nThese vertically-integrated AI startups -- that span everything from tackling defective sewer pipes to streamlining how U.S. citizens apply for government documents -- bring together best-of-breed AI solutions with a deep understanding of their respective sectors with proprietary technology to create end-to-end AI solutions that tackle industry-specific problems.\n\nUsing AI not just to drive efficiency but to increase margin and reduce overhead, these lean, vertically-integrated startups aren't just at the forefront of the next wave of AI, they're part of a new wave of investments in the practical applications of technology.\n\nUsing AI to make it easier to interact with the government\n\nPost-Covid, getting government documents -- like passports or travel visas -- in the U.S. through the traditional channels has been complicated and slow, with many travelers missing trips or getting delayed by application errors.\n\nIn fact, Rep. Adam Schiff recently noted that \"Every day, my office hears from constituents facing terrible delays with their passport applications. It's clear that the State Department, despite their best efforts, is not meeting the increased demand post-pandemic. Slow processing timelines have caused significant stress, imposed financial costs and forced constituents to miss out on important events such as ...", "source": {"uri": "rocketnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243018533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:11:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:11:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:10:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://techround.co.uk/tech/teachers-ai-assistants-save-time/", "title": "How And Why Teachers Are Using AI Assistants To Save Time", "body": "It's no secret that artificial intelligence technology has taken the world by storm, infliltrating just but every major industry, and the education sector has been another major benefactor of this innovative technology.\n\nInitially, when AI was introduced to schools, the focus was on students and how the technology would be able to improve their learning experience. In fact, according to a study conducted by Pearson, many teachers expressed little confidence in their own ability to successfully use AI. Simultaneously, however, the study showed that despite teachers' trepidations, they did and do believe in th potential of AI in the classroom.\n\nEven though teachers were a little slower than students in picking up the tech, recently, innovators in the industry have started pushing forward in creating AI to assist teachers in ways that are effective and easy to use - and it's working.\n\nThis shift has been transformative for the AI industry at large, but most importantly, it's changed the lives of teachers in particular. Not only does this technology help them save time during their busy schedules, giving them more capacity to focus on other aspects of their work, but it also helps them improve the overall quality and consistency of their output and the influence they have on their students.\n\nLet's take a look at the different ways in which AI assistants and general AI tech can be used by teachers, as well as the advantages that AI can have for teachers, schools and, at the end of the day, students.\n\nIn shifting the focus from how AI can help students to how it can be used constructively by educators, innovators needed to properly understand the difference in objectives of each group. One of the most significant obstacles faced by teachers is a lack of time in light of the immense amount of work they need to do on a daily basis, in addition to engaging with students.\n\nThe most important consideration for teachers, therefore, is how to help them do everything they need to do while maintaining a high level of quality and consistency.\n\nIn response to this need, here are some ways AI is now being used to assist teachers:\n\nAI teaching assistants can be used to create an array of different supplementary learning resources that can be incredibly helpful in the classroom. This can include things like lesson plans, informative handouts, tests and assignments.\n\nBy feeding informtion into the AI software, the virtual assistant will be able to produce resources in accordance with the guidelines and parameters set by the teacher.\n\nThat is, a teacher working on creating a history quiz for their students about the American Civil War, for instance, will be able to tell the teaching assistant what they want - including the length of the quiz, the types of questions it ought to include, the level of difficulty of the quiz and more. From there, the software will produce a quiz that meets all these requirements - along with an accurate memo. Quizizz is a great example of this, creating high-quality quizzes for teachers to be used by students - it also boasts additional tools including slideshow generation and more.\n\nOne of the main time-wasters, so to speak, that teachers deal with on a daily basis is the signiificant amount of clerical work they have to do. However, basic clerical work and administration is one of the easiest things for AI to handle, and with AI programmes specially designed for use in school systems, educators are able to automate a lot of work that they used to have to do manually, including:\n\nMagic School is one such AI teaching assistant that teachers can utilise to perform these types of tasks, offering a a diverse range of tools, ranging from generating markig rubrics to creating fun and unique lesson plans. It also operates as an organisational tool for busy teachers.\n\nIndeed, the main challenge involved in having to do these things on a daily basis is the amount of time it takes teachers, who are already limited in that sense, and the difficulty of maintaining high quality and consistency.\n\nNot only do these helpful AI teaching assistants make completing these tasks way quicker, but they also remove a lot of potential for human error and introduce a higher level of consistency.\n\nCreativity is a big and important part of being a teacher, but it can be challenging for those who have been teaching for a long time to constantly produce new and exciting lesson plans, especially when they have so much to do.\n\nNow, AI teaching assistants like Lesson Pilot can use artificial intelligence to give them a helping hand in coming up with and enhancing lesson plans. By feeding these programms prompts regarding the purpose of the activity or lesson, as well as guidelines pertaining to the age group of the students, the subject and more, teachers will have access to unique and createive lesson plans that are tailored to both the teacher and the students' needs.\n\nOne of the potentially most helpful things educators can do in assisting learners is provide them with personalised feedback specifically tailored to their performance and their needs.\n\nHowever, the reality of being able to do this is far more challenging than it sounds, because, among other things, it's incredibly time consuming, and there are only so many hours in the day.\n\nAI teaching assistants are making significant strides in combattig this issue, however, with the ability to assess the performance of students on a personalised level. These programmes can collect data from the class as a whole and analyse it accordingly to advise teachers on learning areas to focus on, as well as areas where students are excelling. They can also provide analysis of individual students' performances, assessing their strengths and weaknesses, something that, for most busy teachers, is simply far too time consuming.\n\nThere are a few AI programmes that have emerged as leaders in this particular area of educational AI, including Pearson's teaching assistant software.\n\nThe idea behind the use of AI in the classroom is to be able to use it as a tool to compliment teachers' skills, rather than replace them, as many seem fear is on the horizon.", "source": {"uri": "techround.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8243103599", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:08:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:08:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:06:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://hbr.org/2024/07/can-ai-help-your-company-innovate-it-depends", "title": "Can AI Help Your Company Innovate? It Depends", "body": "Companies need new ways to innovate quickly, cheaply, and productively. Many, quite reasonably, wonder how deploying AI might help. To investigate, we researched how companies are using AI for innovation and found that tools are just tools -- success depends on how organizations use these new tools now at their disposal. To investigate what kinds of innovation AI worked with, the authors performed two studies: first, a survey of 331 firms for practices on process improvement and new technology development, and second, an archival analysis of patent data on new technology development for a broader sample of more than 2,000 publicly traded firms. The results of these studies suggest that firms that have historically focused on specific types of innovation -- process innovation and innovation by diverse recombination, in which companies combine a wide variety of technology elements in new ways -- may benefit most from using advanced data capabilities of machine learning and AI. Firms that use AI analytics to generate wide recombinations are 3 to 7% more productive than firms that do not. Furthermore, when a firm's existing knowledge is spread throughout the firm, advanced AI capabilities can further boost firm innovation by about three more new patents a year. Conversely, using AI is less helpful for incremental innovation and making small improvements to existing products, and is almost no help at all for radical innovation.", "source": {"uri": "hbr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hbr                                "}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Artificial intelligence"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_recombination", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Genetic recombination"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patent", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Patent"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Machine learning"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytics", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Analytics"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Opportunities/Inventions", "label": "dmoz/Business/Opportunities/Inventions", "wgt": 20}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Technology/Invention_and_Innovation", "label": "dmoz/Science/Technology/Invention and Innovation", "wgt": 25}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Artificial_Intelligence/Games", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Artificial Intelligence/Games", "wgt": 22}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Artificial_Intelligence/Philosophy", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Artificial Intelligence/Philosophy", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "news/Technology", "label": "news/Technology", "wgt": 45}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Biology/Biologists", "label": "dmoz/Science/Biology/Biologists", "wgt": 23}], "image": "https://hbr.org/resources/images/article_assets/2024/07/Jul24_25_2003100693.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761468", "eventUri": "eng-9761468", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.607843137254902, "wgt": 116, "relevance": 1}

By leveraging AI, banks can offer tailored financial products, enhance customer engagement & experiences, and streamline operations. AI's predictive capabilities enable proactive fraud detection and mitigate financial risks, while its automation prowess easily manages repetitive tasks, freeing up resources to focus on complex customer needs and strategic initiatives. From chatbots providing 24/7 customer support to AI-driven credit scoring for expedited loan approvals, the impact of AI in Retail Banking is transformative and profound.\n\nEmbracing an AI-first approach in retail banking is not without its challenges. The twin challenges often faced by organizations are lack of a clear strategy for AI adoption and being data-ready to fully exploit AI capabilities. Banks often struggle to move from experimentation around select use cases to scaling AI technologies across the organization.
