{"uri": "2024-07-433693558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:35:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:35:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:32:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.arabnews.com/node/2556646", "title": "Training an Arabic LLM that reflects local values", "body": "Advances in the large language models that underpin generative AI are changing everything, from medicine and education to entertainment.\n\nOur relationship with technology is becoming more intimate as machines change from passive tools into active assistants that amplify our innate human abilities.\n\nThis new era poses both a challenge and an opportunity for the Middle East.\n\nThe challenge is that leaders in this new field, like OpenAI's ChatGPT and Google's Gemini, come from Silicon Valley, or from China, where my team at 01.AI has built models that rival the Americans. In Europe, too, startups such as France's Mistral have entered the race.\n\nThe opportunity is for the Middle East to join this league and make sure its voice is heard.\n\nInspired by my latest trip to Riyadh, I decided to test how the current crop of AI models would handle a simple request. I imagined myself as a young Saudi getting ready to host a dinner party and asked ChatGPT to prepare a menu.\n\nThe food it recommended sounded delicious -- stuffed grape leaves, tabouleh salad, mandi and stuffed dates. But the beverages were a problem.\n\nAside from drinks such as mint lemonade and jallab, a mixture of dates, grape molasses and rose water, ChatGPT also offered this: \"For alcoholic beverages, you could offer a selection of international wines, beers, or non-alcoholic mocktails.\"\n\nTo its credit, when I repeated the question, it offered only non-alcoholic drinks.\n\nIf a model recommends breaking both the law and cultural norms, imagine how it might answer other more sensitive questions about politics or religion? Indeed, researchers have even shown that some models have exhibited an anti-Muslim bias.\n\nMy modest test underlines the urgent need to develop an Arabic large language model that reflects local values.\n\nThe first step to building this is creating enough high-quality Arabic digitized data to properly train a new generation of models.\n\nAlthough there are 400 million Arabic speakers, only an estimated 2 percent of online content is in Arabic. Meta's open source LLM model Llama is overwhelmingly trained on English data, with Arabic comprising less than 0.1 percent of the data.\n\nThe lack of data naturally skews the results. To fix this dearth of data, either a visionary entrepreneur or a government-backed organization should collect, digitize and convert the many Arabic books into training data for Arabic models.\n\nOnce the data is gathered, it can be fed into the breakthrough pre-training process, which reads trillions of words and creates its own virtual concept space or model of the world. This concept space has been shown to be mostly in English and Chinese.\n\nAdding a sizable number of texts in Arabic, which has enormous cultural output and significance, will make the concept space more knowledgeable about Arabic and more balanced in its concepts and views.\n\nAfter such pre-training, the model needs to be fine-tuned by data and labels from the Arab world, which will align with the values of the region. Those are different from American models, which are aligned to US values, and Chinese models, which reflect Chinese values.\n\nThe collection of alignment data, the coordination of human labeling and the alignment process will need to be done in-region by AI experts.\n\nA new Arabic-enhanced large language model could encourage entrepreneurs and developers to build new applications tailored to the needs of their nations.\n\nKai-fu Lee\n\nFinally, safety modules will need to be added to ensure legal compliance and to avoid harm. These will also need to be developed locally.\n\nThe above steps will create localized, sovereign models that will reflect the traditions of the Middle East. Privately developed or government-backed, it could be the foundation for a new wave of Arabic AI innovation.\n\nA new Arabic-enhanced large language model could encourage entrepreneurs and developers to build new applications tailored to the needs of their nations.\n\nImagine an AI tool that could find, summarize, organize and write insightful content, an AI teacher that makes learning fun and customized, an AI doctor that is more knowledgeable than any human, an AI engineer that can write software and applications, and an AI assistant that knows its owner better than the owner themselves.\n\nThe Arab world did not play a leading role in the PC, internet and mobile eras. In the AI era, it will be different.\n\nThis transformation is by no means an easy feat. It will require an unprecedented investment of money, energy and human capital.\n\nMiddle Eastern leaders like Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and others have shown that they have the vision, determination and resources to lead their countries into the future.\n\nStanding on my hotel balcony in Jeddah recently, overlooking the King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, I saw part of that vision coming to fruition.\n\nUniversities such as KAUST and the Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence in the UAE are striking examples of the resources that have already been poured into this transformation.\n\nThese world-class academic institutions can attract and retain the best top tier global talent. \u202fIt is especially important to bring in the world's best computer engineers to help fulfill this vision of the future AI.\n\nOur team at 01.AI has shown what a group of talented and motivated computer scientists can achieve in just one year. With the right commitment of resources and drawing upon the best talent, countries like Saudi Arabia can easily catch up with their global peers.\n\nThe Middle East can also lead the world in the use of renewables to run power-hungry generative AI models.\n\nAs it seeks to diversify its economy, Saudi Arabia is actively promoting the use of alternative energy sources such as solar, which could power server farms and reduce their carbon footprint -- a growing concern as AI becomes more widespread.\n\nIt may take time for countries to figure out their strategy for building a sovereign AI. But it is critical for the Arab world to quickly catalyze the creation of culturally appropriate LLMs and build a rich ecosystem to allow AI-powered Arabic apps to blossom.\n\nA recent encounter with a female sales assistant at a computer store in Riyadh served as an apt reminder of what is at stake. Dressed in jeans and sporting a tattoo, she was a reminder of the transformative changes that the country is undergoing.\n\nWhere are you from, I asked. \"I'm Saudi,\" she said. \"One day I want to be Saudi Arabia's Elon Musk.\" I hope on my next visit she will pitch me a homegrown AI app.\n\n* Kai-Fu Lee is a computer scientist, CEO of 01.AI, chairman of Sinovation Ventures, former president of Google China, and author of \"AI 2041\" and \"AI Superpowers\"", "source": {"uri": "arabnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243452214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:14:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:14:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:13:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://dzone.com/articles/the-impact-of-generative-ai-in-telecom-software", "title": "Impact of Generative AI - DZone", "body": "The telecommunications industry, known for its constant evolution and technological advancements, is on the brink of a transformative shift with the integration of Generative AI (Gen AI). This emerging technology promises and is poised to revolutionize telecom operators' operational methodologies, customer interactions, and service delivery. Let's explore the potential of Gen AI and its exciting future for telecommunication.\n\nLet's dive deep.\n\nGenerative AI is a sophisticated subset of artificial intelligence that harnesses the power of deep learning (DL) algorithms to create digital content like images, videos, and audio that mimics the quality and complexity of human-generated output.\n\nAt the heart of Gen AI lies its ability to utilize neural networks - intricate webs of interconnected nodes. These networks undergo rigorous training to discern and internalize patterns within massive data pools. When fully trained, these networks can produce novel content. This process starts with a random input, known as a 'seed value,' which serves as the initial point for content generation. The network then progressively refines the output to enhance realism and coherence.\n\nThe integration of Gen AI, in synergy with Machine Learning (ML), is poised to revolutionize mobile telecommunications, particularly in network orchestration and management. This technological synergy is set to overhaul traditional approaches to telecom operations by injecting automation into complex decision-making processes, enabling predictive responses to real-time network scenarios, and significantly enhancing overall network efficiency.\n\nOne of the most compelling aspects of Gen AI in Telecom is its potential to optimize resource distribution within the network. This capability ensures the streamlined operation of telecom services and opens avenues for innovation in service delivery. Telecom operators equipped with Gen AI tools can now foresee network demands, preemptively allocate resources, and ensure optimal network performance, thus elevating the user experience to unprecedented levels and instilling a sense of reassurance in our readers about the future of telecom services.\n\nFurthermore, Gen AI's potential in the telecom industry goes beyond just improving operational efficiency. It includes various applications such as enhancing customer service through AI-driven interactions, offering personalized services, and implementing advanced security protocols to protect the network against emerging cyber threats. This not only ensures a more secure network but also improves the customer experience, creating an optimistic outlook for the future of telecom interactions among our readers.\n\nGen AI in Telecom is crucial for optimizing the network and providing top-notch customer service. Here are some critical use cases that illustrate its importance:\n\nThe telecom industry's utilization of generative artificial intelligence has led to network optimization for unmatched efficiency. This is achieved through machine learning and autonomous data pattern analysis, which predicts potential bottlenecks and optimizes resource allocation. Generative AI is a powerful tool for independent network management, ensuring peak efficiency and enhancing the reliability of the telecommunications infrastructure.\n\nThe integration of generative AI-powered chatbots is poised to transform customer service in the telecommunications sector. These intelligent virtual assistants promptly respond to customer inquiries, improving customer satisfaction and allowing human agents to focus on personalized service and intricate tasks.\n\nGenerative AI enables telecom providers to shift from reactive to proactive by employing predictive maintenance. Analyzing historical data for patterns that predict potential equipment failures allows for intervention before disruptions occur, minimizing service downtime and instilling confidence in the reliability of operations.\n\nGiven the telecom industry's susceptibility to cyber threats, the preventive measures enabled by generative AI solutions are crucial. Generative AI actively tracks changes in customer behaviors and threats, adapting to emerging risks as cybersecurity evolves and providing robust defense against data loss and network integrity.\n\nGenerative AI in Telecom equips telcos with comprehensive data analytics features, uncovering high-value information and identifying emerging trends for informed decision-making. This technology helps predict future trends in the telecom market and fosters adaptability and continuous improvement within the industry.\n\nIn wireless communication systems, channel coding improves performance by addressing parameters like bit and packet error rates and computational complexity. It can detect or correct errors, and Gen AI methods are used for encoder and decoder processes. These Gen AI methods optimize error correction codes, improving outcomes, including list decoding for polar codes.\n\nIntelligent spectrum management is essential for cellular networks, using AI-powered services to optimize the allocation and use of spectrum resources. With increasing connectivity demands and a crowded radio frequency environment, AI optimizes network performance, reduces interference, and ensures efficient spectrum usage. The benefits of AI-powered spectrum management are vast, promising an optimistic future for wireless technologies. It enables various wireless technologies to coexist and supports seamless and reliable connectivity for an improved wireless experience.\n\nAI-driven beamforming and antenna arrays use advanced techniques to improve signal transmission and coverage, especially in mm-wave frequencies. With 5G nearing finalization, research on 6G networks has commenced. Reflective intelligent surfaces (RISs) show promise for 6G networks, providing greater flexibility in customizing channel characteristics.\n\nAI will be increasingly crucial in cellular networks to maximize resource usage, reduce energy consumption, and support environmentally friendly communication solutions. Considering ecological impact assessments, energy usage analysis, resource allocation, inclusivity, and fairness is vital when planning future strategies. Integrating AI into cellular networks allows one to address concerns about inclusivity and fairness and bridge the digital divide. AI algorithms also help adjust network configuration based on energy availability and environmental conditions, leading to eco-friendly communication infrastructures.\n\nGen AI integration into satellite communications promises to revolutionize global coverage and disaster response in cellular networks. Gen AI-powered satellite networks can swiftly detect disasters, optimize communication resources, and seamlessly integrate with terrestrial cellular networks, IoT devices, and edge computing systems. This integration would significantly expand worldwide connectivity and facilitate convergence across diverse network infrastructures, leading to revolutionary advancements.\n\nCellular and IoT networks will feature greater autonomy, with Gen AI-driven self-healing, self-organizing, and self-optimizing capabilities. The strain on mobile networks due to the rapid growth of new applications and services can be managed using innovative network automation solutions, such as zero-touch management methods. Blockchain-based intelligent systems can streamline deployment across application and infrastructure domains, ensuring high performance while relieving users of costs, security, and resource allocation concerns.\n\nFuture wireless networks require large-scale distributed machine learning (ML) for mobile Gen AI applications but face communication bottlenecks. Exploring cellular network technologies is crucial. Cloud-based solutions could be more effective due to delays, power consumption, and security risks. Integrating edge computing and Gen AI can strategically deploy efficient computing servers near network edges to enhance performance. This setup can improve the capabilities of advanced Gen AI applications and reduce potential privacy breaches. Integrating Gen AI techniques for end-to-end communications has gained attention, leading to the development of native Gen AI wireless networks.\n\nGen AI-powered network slicing is a transformative force in network provisioning and management. It involves creating customizable network segments tailored to specific industries and applications and plays a crucial role in cellular networks. The AI algorithms allocate resources intelligently based on traffic patterns and user behaviors, increasing resource utilization and improving user experiences. This approach allows for precise customization of networks for various applications, revolutionizing network provisioning and management and supporting an intelligent future.\n\nMIMO (multiple-input, multiple-output) and beamforming are crucial for increasing cellular network capacity. The next generation of cellular systems leverages these technologies to multiply radio link capacity and allocate power effectively. Gen AI methods play a significant role in accurately estimating channels and optimizing massive MIMO systems. This advancement improves spectrum efficiency and leads to more accurate outcomes.\n\nGen AI enhances network efficiency, security, and marketing efforts and revolutionizes customer service. Telecom providers need to adopt Gen AI to stay competitive, as it improves efficiency, customer experience, and business resilience. Optimizing networks, revolutionizing customer service, and strengthening cybersecurity are not just possibilities but inevitable parts of the telecommunication evolution.\n\nSoftware developers in Telecom must adopt generative AI capabilities, driven by the inevitability of innovation in this dynamic and ever-evolving industry.", "source": {"uri": "dzone.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
